BACK TO THE PARK, (70'S ROCK CONT.)
IN A CAVERNOUS HALL, (60'S ROCK MUSIC CONT.)
BACK TO AN OBJECTIVE VIEW OF THE ROOM
I_ HAVE NOTHING TO SAY TO YOU
ALL SOUND BEGINS TO FADE A7
I WILL NOT WIN THIS WAY...DO YOU
IN A NATANYA HOTEL ROOM, (70'S ROCK CONT.)
EXT. SANTA MONICA TOURNAMENT HALL, NIGHT
BOBBY IS INVISIBLE IN THIS ADULT WORLD
IN A HOTEL ROOM, (70'S ROCK CONT.)
...-GET THE FUCK OUTTA HERE. I WANT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the grey dawn, a formidable house in the Icelandic wilderness. A single light burns in an upper window. Caption: Reykjavik, Iceland 4:15am. July 20th, 1972 In the distance, a POLICE CAR approaches, lights flashing

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on a hand gripping the padded arm of an armchair. T index finger of the hand is PICKING at a thread. The HAND belongs to an intense young man with black hair swept back. He sits motionless, peering at a chess game which is a few moves old. The man is BOBBY FISCHER. A SINGLE FLY begins to buzz against the window. Bobby eyes the fly. The movement of his eyes is immense. Murderous. The thread he has been picking at suddenly TEA with a THUNDEROUS RIPPING SOUND. The fly is trying to get out the window.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY'S PERCEPTION
dialogues.text: The BUZZING of the fly is a howling hurricane from hell.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO AN OBJECTIVE VIEW OF THE ROOM
dialogues.text: Silence. Bobby stalks the fly -- CRUSHING IT with a coffee cup. He sits back down in a business-like way and stares at th board again, his fingernail beginning to work another thr HEADLIGHTS sweep the room and we HEAR a car door SLAM. Bobby's face betrays no reaction -- but his whole hand CL the arm of the chair like an animal in a trap. At the SOUND of someone running upstairs, he glances from the chessboard to the door, as a knock comes on the door:

dialogues.speaker: B7
dialogues.text: Pink Revision 10-01-13 2.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY'S PERCEPTION 5
dialogues.text: Someone is POUNDING on the door -- it SOUNDS like the Ges in an old war movie.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO AN OBJECTIVE VIEW 6
dialogues.text: The knock on the door is polite. Bobby grips the armchair, can't stand the noise that only can hear -- and he gets to his feet, UPENDING a lamp. Another knock. Bobby pinballs around like the fly trying to escape -- breaking shutters as he tries to close them, tripping ove table. ANOTHER KNOCK, even louder. Then, just as suddenly, his eyes FOCUS on the chess board A new light comes into his eyes as he stares at it -- and his breathing begins to slow.

dialogues.speaker: ALL SOUND BEGINS TO FADE A7
dialogues.text: As he moves toward the board -- his fingers reaching out in ultra slo-mo -- to make...a...single...move.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO THE SCENE B7
dialogues.text: Bobby closes his eyes. Content. He has solved the puzzle. CAPTION: This is the true story of Bobby Fischer. The door opens. A guy stands there -- mid-40's, pugnaciou This is MARSHALL. He stares at the debris of the room. An at Bobby, who appears perfectly calm.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: There was a fly. It's dead now. A huge agenda between the two men. Marshall composes hims

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: (quoting) "Never before in human history has the outcome of an entire global war of ideas rested on the shoulders of one man." The slightest smile begins to form on Bobby's lips.  Pink Revision 10-01-13 3.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm quoting the President of the United States. He was talking about you. Tome. The President of the United States talking to me. He called three times. Three. Marshall lifts the receiver, places a phone back on the h

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He's been trying to reach you. Bobby refuses to be intimidated. If anything, his smile widens. Marshall rights an upturned chair.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In Moscow, Brezhnev opened his only bottle of 1868 Louis Roederer. Left over from the revolution. You know why? (hammering it home) Because. He. Heard. You Quit. Bobby walks to the window, looks out at the half-light.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There are boys your age in Vietnam giving their lives right now in the fight against Communism. And all you have to do is win a game of chess. (plaintively) ...Say something. Bobby, please... Bobby? Bobby doesn't answer. Instead, he stares out into the nig and we HEAR another voice.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: .. Bobby?

dialogues.speaker: IN THE FISCHER APARTMENT
dialogues.text: Bobby, age 8, stands looking out another window. It is 19 JOAN, Bobby's sister, 14, comes up beside him.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Bobby, it's bedtime.  Yellow Revision 10-11-13 4.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: That man's out there. Joan looks out. A SEDAN is parked under a streetlight. A LIT MATCH briefly illuminates a MAN'S FACE as he lights a cigarette. Is that a telephoto lens in his hand? She subt turns him away from the window.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Have you eaten anything? There's actually food in the house. Go. Bobby heads back into a party in full swing. The apartmen is packed with Boho's, Eastern European emigres, NY intellectuals. A banner reads, "Brooklyn-Bed Sty American Communist Party PARTY! Coltrane wails on the record playe

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY IS INVISIBLE IN THIS ADULT WORLD
dialogues.text: Adults LOOM above him, laughing. A MIXED COUPLE making ou open-mouthed. A man smoking reefer smiles beatifically. H pauses to scribble chess notations in his little notebook

dialogues.speaker: PARTY GUEST
dialogues.text: Half the witnesses they call are Communists, the other half are Jews!

dialogues.speaker: PARTY GUEST
dialogues.text: If you're both, do you testify twice?

dialogues.speaker: PARTY GUEST
dialogues.text: You can make jokes, Mr. Liberal -- your entire family wasn't gassed in the camps, alava'shalom. Regina, meanwhile, is in the middle of of an intense conversation with a BALDING MAN. They WHISPER harshly.

dialogues.speaker: REGINA
dialogues.text: We agreed he wouldn't know who you are--!

dialogues.speaker: BALDING MAN
dialogues.text: Fine. But that doesn't mean----  Yellow Revision 10-11-13 5.

dialogues.speaker: REGINA
dialogues.text: --So I don't see the point!

dialogues.speaker: BALDING MAN
dialogues.text: The point is--- Christ, just let me talk to him, then I'll go...

dialogues.speaker: IN THE DIRTY KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Bobby is making a sandwich. The BALDING MAN approaches.

dialogues.speaker: BALDING MAN
dialogues.text: Howdy doody, Bobby...

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Hullo.

dialogues.speaker: BALDING MAN
dialogues.text: Remember me...?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Sort of.

dialogues.speaker: BALDING MAN
dialogues.text: I'm your Uncle Paul. From Denver. How's school?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: BALDING MAN
dialogues.text: Studying hard?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I guess.

dialogues.speaker: BALDING MAN
dialogues.text: Ever heard of Physics?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BALDING MAN
dialogues.text: But you're good in Math?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I guess. The man stares at him -- there's something pregnant and unspoken in his regard -- but also somehow thwarted.

dialogues.speaker: BALDING MAN
dialogues.text: I hear you like chess.  10 Yellow Revision 10-11-13 6.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Yeah. He looks around, takes a five dollar bill from his pocket

dialogues.speaker: BALDING MAN
dialogues.text: Here. Buy a new set. Just don't tell your mother where it came from... Bobby's eyes widen as he stares at the bill. The man reac out to HUG him, but Bobby shrinks away. Uncle Paul frowns settles for patting Bobby on the head and then walks away

dialogues.speaker: IN THE LIVING ROOM 10
dialogues.text: A heated discussion of Zionism, the Rosenbergs. Bobby wan past, looks out the window. The DARK SEDAN is still there Regina is nearby, deep in conversation -- IN RUSSIAN.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Mama-—

dialogues.speaker: REGINA
dialogues.text: Not now, honey.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I have to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: REGINA
dialogues.text: Honey, it's past your bedtime.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: That car's down there again. Regina's antennae go up.

dialogues.speaker: REGINA
dialogues.text: What car?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: You told me to tell you... A red, 1951 Chevy, NY license plate HI62579. Regina apologizes to her friend in Russian, kneels down.  Yellow Revision 10-11-13 7.

dialogues.speaker: REGINA
dialogues.text: Honey, it's okay--

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: But you told me--

dialogues.speaker: REGINA
dialogues.text: Bobby, you remember what I said about not letting them intimidate us? Yes, they watch us -- because we represent something very threatening to them, to the status quo. You remember what that is?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (by rote) Revolution.

dialogues.speaker: REGINA
dialogues.text: Yes! And sometimes these bad people want to know about our work so they spy on us. So if someone comes up to you on the street and asks you questions about me, or Mommy's friends, what do you say?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (by rote) I_have nothing to say to you.

dialogues.speaker: REGINA
dialogues.text: That's my big boy. (to Joan) Joanie, he's got mustard on his shirt. He has to wear that to school tomorrow. Soak it for me?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Love to. She takes Bobby's hand and leads him away.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bedtime for Bonzo. She tickles as she leads him toward the bedroom  11 Pink Revision 10-01-13

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby lies in bed, wide awake. We HEAR the noise of the party outside -- loud conversation, boisterous laughter. 7A. 11  12 13 Yellow Revision 10-11-13 8. Bobby stares at the window -- is the man still out there? We feel his anxiety building as he LISTENS INTENTLY to th sound of the shade SLAPPING against the window sill. Suddenly, he sits up, opens a drawer. He works fast -- li someone breaking the rules -- lights a candle -- rolls th wax into balls and stuffs them into his ears. The laughter outside is muted. Bobby stuffs a ball into his other ear. With both ears blocked -- a sudden and wonderful silence! Bobby carries the candle to a CHESSBOARD. In absolute sil he stares at the chessboard. In his hand is the NOTEBOOK. CLOSE on Bobby's face, candlelit, a study in intensity. As Bobby stares at the chessboard, everything else in the room literally begins to disappear. The bed, the crummy dresser -- until all that is left is a boy and a chessboa

dialogues.speaker: THE CHESSBOARD 12
dialogues.text: Pieces move on their own. Multiple exposures. A move yiel hundreds of options. The counter offers thousands more. CLOSE on Bobby's face. Ethereal Music. Bliss. Then...

dialogues.speaker: THE DOOR TO HIS BEDROOM IS FLUNG OPEN 13
dialogues.text: Light floods in. Harsh SOUNDS. The spell is broken. The two open-mouthed kissers are looking for a place to fuck.

dialogues.speaker: KISSING MAN
dialogues.text: Whoopsee-daisy... (sees Bobby) Sorry, kiddo.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Get out of my room. GET OUT! Regina appears behind them.

dialogues.speaker: REGINA
dialogues.text: Bobby! Those are our guests! (sees his chessboard) Jesus, enough already with the chess! She reaches for the board. Pieces fall, ruining the game.

dialogues.speaker: REGINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (calling out) Joan--!  14 15 Yellow Revision 10-11-13 9. Joan appears.

dialogues.speaker: REGINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Put him to bed, will ya? As Regina returns to the party. Joan kneels to pick up th fallen pieces. Bobby looks up at her.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Please...?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Okay. One game. She sits beside him on the bed and sets up the board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby, Joan and Regina sit in a waiting room. Regina smoo Bobby's hair.

dialogues.speaker: REGINA
dialogues.text: Now Bobby, don't suddenly start acting normal and make me look ridiculous...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On DOCTOR MENGARINI's desk is a LARGE WOODEN CHESS SET. Across the desk we find Bobby. The game is fifteen moves old. Smoke from Megarini's pipe wafts among the chess pie

dialogues.speaker: MENGARINI
dialogues.text: So Bobby, you go to the movies? (Bobby nods without looking up) You like Westerns? Bang, bang? Bobby nods again. Mengarini glances at Regina.

dialogues.speaker: REGINA
dialogues.text: Bobby, have you ever been to the Moon on the subway? Bobby nods and moves a piece. He's in a kind of trance.

dialogues.speaker: REGINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Once I poured a glass of water over his head... Mengarini studies Bobby as Bobby studies the board.

dialogues.speaker: REGINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If I take the pieces away he just plays in his head. Day and night.  Yellow Revision 10-11-13 Mengarini moves his knight. Bobby counters.

dialogues.speaker: MENGARINI
dialogues.text: What do you dream about, Bobby? Silence. Regina shrugs. Mengarini takes Bobby's rook. 9A.  Green Revision 10-14-13 10.

dialogues.speaker: MENGARINI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You like Parchesi? Monopoly? (to Joan) Does he play other games with you?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: He says chess is the only game that doesn't need luck. Mengarini has barely finished moving when Bobby makes a m This startles Mengarini, who frowns at the new positions.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And he cries when he loses. Bobby glares at her briefly then returns his focus to the game. Mengarini squints at the board, then makes his move

dialogues.speaker: MENGARINI
dialogues.text: I play chess at quite a high level. His game is pretty good. Not exceptional, though. (magnanimous1ly) A draw? Bobby isn't listening. He's in the zone. He initiates an exchange: his Queen takes Mengarini's Bishop. Mengarini grunts, makes another move. Then Bobby pounces. Mengarini tries to escape but the trap has been sprung. After several moves it's clear he's doomed. Mengarini is astonished. Bobby looks up at him -- somethi new and...well...murderous in his expression.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: He hates draws.

dialogues.speaker: MENGARINI
dialogues.text: Where the hell did that come from?

dialogues.speaker: REGINA
dialogues.text: So now you see. Mengarini is still staring at the board in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: MENGARINI
dialogues.text: Who taught him to play like this?  16 17 Yellow Revision 10-11-13 11.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: I bought him the set. Last year.

dialogues.speaker: MENGARINI
dialogues.text: Which club does his belong to?

dialogues.speaker: REGINA
dialogues.text: He doesn't belong to any club. He taught himself.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I need to pee. Joan takes Bobby's hand and leads him out the door.

dialogues.speaker: REGINA
dialogues.text: So, Doctor. What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: MENGARINI
dialogues.text: Mrs. Fischer, there are worse things than playing chess. Believe me.

dialogues.speaker: REGINA
dialogues.text: He wants there to be nothing else. Mengarini is now writing on a pad.

dialogues.speaker: MENGARINI
dialogues.text: I think he should see a professional.

dialogues.speaker: REGINA
dialogues.text: I thought you were a professional. He hands her the note. "Carmine Nigro, Brooklyn Chess Clu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan and Bobby walk down a Brooklyn street, arriving at a shabby storefront where A Hispanic MAN, 30's, is waiting.

dialogues.speaker: CARMINE
dialogues.text: You must be the Fischers. I'm Carmine Nigro. (to Bobby) I'm betting you're the chess player.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Bobby, say hello. Bobby mumbles hello. Carmine unlocks the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Carmine turns on the lights, we WATCH Bobby's face as room is revealed -- twenty tables, all with boards set up  Yellow Revision 10-11-13 12.

dialogues.speaker: CARMINE
dialogues.text: Our church. All colors and creeds welcome. Bobby walks in as if entering a holy place. The door behi them bursts opens and Regina bustles in.

dialogues.speaker: REGINA
dialogues.text: Sorry sorry the E train was a nightmare -- you must be Camine Nigro I'm Regina Fischer. So....?

dialogues.speaker: CARMINE
dialogues.text: Doctor Mengarini says he's good. But most young people don't have the concentration to play at this level so please don't build up your hopes.

dialogues.speaker: REGINA
dialogues.text: My 'hopes' are he will give up on the damn game if someone beats him.

dialogues.speaker: CARMINE
dialogues.text: Okay, let's see what we got here... He grabs two chess pieces, one black and one white, holds them behind his back and turns to Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: CARMINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Choose. TIME CUT: As the game begins, Carmine seems confident. Bo makes a move that draws him up short. TIME CUT: Bobby's moves grow bolder, Carmine's body langu is changing. The fight is on. TIME CUT: Carmine has to use all his wiles. Eventually, though, he begins to win, and soon he has Bobby trapped. Bobby stares at the board, his face reddening. He has los He HATES to lose. He pushes his chair back and walks away fighting back tears. Carmine turns to Regina.

dialogues.speaker: CARMINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, I am officially the twenty- fifth best chess player in New York City. But he has great potential. Suddenly, a piece is SLAPPED back on the board. Bobby has returned and starts replacing pieces.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Again.  Green Revision 10-14-13 12A-12B. We can't help but see the ferocity in his eyes. Al18 TIME CUT - THE BROOKLYN CHESS CLUB A18* A spectator pushes his way through a crowd gathered aroun the young phenom. *

dialogues.speaker: 50'S ROCK AND ROLL KICKS IN 18
dialogues.text: As _ we follow Bobby's rise to fame. In THE BROOKLYN CHES CLUB, a small crowd watches him play. At a tournament -- Carmine by his side -- he defeats ONE OPPONENT AFTER ANOT Regina watches intently. We see Bobby studying chess as he makes a sandwich, study as he walks down the street, asleep with his head on a bo In the gym, We FOCUS on his hands as he moves his pieces what we will come to know as his signature SLAPPING gestu INTERCUT multiple exposures of Bobby's HANDS with NEWSREE FOOTAGE of the next five years: the Rosenbergs are execut  Green Revision 10-14-13 13. Playboy bunnies are introduced; revolution in Hungary; ho hoops, missile launches, A-bomb tests, duck-and-cover. The images SPEED UP and PROLIFERATE, Bobby's hands becomi a BLUR as the soundtrack BUILDS -- until, when we return normal speed, the CAMERA PANS UP FROM THE HANDS TO REVEAL

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: He's playing against a man in his 20's.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSREEL ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ..-Bobby Fischer played American Master Donald Byrne today and beat him in what is already being described as the Game of the Century. A21 IMAGES OF BOBBY - DOC STYLE (50'S ROCK AND ROLL CONT. shaking hands with opponents, being handed a big gold med

dialogues.speaker: 50'S REPORTER
dialogues.text: So Bobby, congratulations. What's next for you?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I don't know, my game's getting pretty strong... Bobby blinks into the camera, hoists his medal.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSREEL ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: With the longest string of victories in the history of the competition, Bobby Fischer today became the youngest ever United States Chess Champion--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby wears a sharp suit, a strut in his stride. He carri a large paper bag and a trophy. A KID yells as he passes.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKLYN KID
dialogues.text: Hey, Jewboy, way to go! The other kids laugh but Bobby is oblivious, he's clearly playing chess in his head.  23 Green Revision 10-14-13 14.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby has taken a roll of aluminum foil from the paper ba and is covering a window. The trophy has been thrown haphazardly on a sofa. The TV is on: ERIC SEVEREID (on TV) .-Today, the Soviet Union announced it has successfully launched the first satellite to reach outer space. Its name is Sputnik. He doesn't hear Joan as she enters carrying groceries.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: You live under a rock? The Russians are gonna shoot missiles at us from space.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: And you think aluminum foil will keep out radiation?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Hey, I'm not the one planning to fry the world. You're gonna have a kid. You should think about digging a shelter. Joan sees the trophy, lying on the kitchen table.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Congratulations. Wish you'd let us come...

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Mom? Can't concentrate when she's there. (looks around) Where is she, anyway--?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Ban-the-bomb march in Union Square. Bobby is distracted by a chess game-in-progress. Makes a move.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Be a hoot if she got blown up by a Commie nuke while marching against America.  24 25 Yellow Revision 10-11-13 15.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: She's not marching against America. She's marching for peace.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Yeah? Chaining herself to the White House...

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: It's just... Mom.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (suddenly distracted) --What day is it?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Friday.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: No. The date. THE DATE!

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: The 26th. Without a word, Bobby is heading out.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where you going? Too late. He's outta there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A slice of Moscow in New York. A samovar. Everyone smokin Russian spoken in hushed whispers. The middle-aged BOOKST CLERK knows Bobby when he enters.

dialogues.speaker: BOOKSTORE OWNER
dialogues.text: It just came in. He points to the magazine rack. Bobby reverently picks up the latest Shakmanty Bulletin and dives in -- his eyes MEMORIZING each diagram at a glance -- his photographic m like a motor-driven CAMERA. Cachunk. Cachunk. Cachunk.

dialogues.speaker: FROM OUTSIDE THE STORE
dialogues.text: A different POV. The store is under FBI Surveillance. Cli

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby lets himself in. He sees Regina's shoes just inside the door and A PAIR OF SIZE 12 SHOES beside them. Frowns.  26 Pink Revision 10-01-13 15A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is little changed -- except for dozens of TROPHI strewn haphazardly, and stacks upon stacks of chess magaz Bobby opens to a page -- and there we SEE the handsome fa of Boris Spassky -- the Soviet Grandmaster.  27 28 29 Yellow Revision 10-11-13 16. Bobby studies a DIAGRAM of Spassky's latest game. He plac his pieces. Working fast. Slap. Slap. He's in the zone. Then...from the bedroom, the SOUNDS of a man and woman ha sex. Bobby puts his fingers in his ears, closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE BOBBY'S HEAD 27
dialogues.text: The columns of numbers are jumbled, faded. A SOUND intrud

dialogues.speaker: BACK IN THE ROOM 28
dialogues.text: Bobby HEARS a toilet flush. The SOUND of laughter. A bed creaking. It's all too much. Bobby LEAPS to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE LIVING ROOM 29
dialogues.text: Bobby finds Regina in her robe.

dialogues.speaker: REGINA
dialogues.text: You're back! And you won! Congratulations! Bobby walks to the Size 12 shoes and picks them up.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Every night I hear you two fuck. Fuck fuck fuck. Bang! Bang! Bang!

dialogues.speaker: REGINA
dialogues.text: Bobby, put those down. A big man -- CYRIL -- appears in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: CYRIL
dialogues.text: Bobby--

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I got nothing to say to you. You live in my house but you're not my father, okay?

dialogues.speaker: REGINA
dialogues.text: Bobby--

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Where's my real father?

dialogues.speaker: REGINA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I was born, right? What'd you do with him? Is he on earth? Does he exist?  Yellow Revision 10-11-13 17.

dialogues.speaker: REGINA
dialogues.text: Honey, it was a long time ago...

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: And you can't remember? Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: REGINA
dialogues.text: Gone.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Gone where?

dialogues.speaker: REGINA
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter--

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: That's nice. My real father doesn't matter but Mr. Bigfoot, he matters..!

dialogues.speaker: REGINA
dialogues.text: Bobby--

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Gone where? When? Who? WHY?

dialogues.speaker: REGINA
dialogues.text: Baby, it's late... Bobby holds the man-size shoes out the open kitchen windo

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Now. Regina deflates. Holds her head. Sighs. Sighs again.

dialogues.speaker: REGINA
dialogues.text: .+-Paul died two years ago. I think you knew that.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Paul? Paul who? ..... UNCLE Paul--? Regina can barely meet his gaze. Yes. Uncle Paul.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: HE was my father? And you never told me? And now he's DEAD?! (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 30 Yellow Revision 10-11-13 18.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (starts pacing)

dialogues.speaker: BIGFOOT...TO LEAVE
dialogues.text: He FLINGS the shoes out into the street.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go back to Moscow with your Commie friends. I am in training. I am studying day and night to be world champion, do you understand? The youngest world champion...ever! I NEED SILENCE AROUND HERE! Do you understand! I. WANT..... SILENCE!!! He storms out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan makes her way through the misfits, poets and drifter playing chess in the open air. She finds Bobby asleep at the chess tables. His suit is wrinkled and filthy.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Carmine said you're staying at the chess club.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Quiet there.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: What about high school?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Ha. Is she still there? She sits beside him.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: She fixed up the apartment. Even got the hot water heater working. Bobby looks at her, sensing an agenda.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She won't be living there anymore. (holds up the key) She's going to do politics in California with Cyril.  Yellow Revision 10-11-13 19.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: You mean King Kong.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: She thought if they went away you'd go home and sleep in a bed.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: That's what she told you? And you bought it? (stands up) She's running away with some nut- case-Big Foot-communist and, oh you know what? It's for Bobby's benefit!

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: You said you wanted quiet. (looks at him) You won, Bobby. Be happy.

dialogues.speaker: AN INTERVIEW 31
dialogues.text: Hand-held, grainy black-and-white.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Bobby Fischer Interview. Take One. (hits the slate) So, Bobby, how long before you get a shot at the title?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: The Federation makes it very difficult to advance in the rankings. Gonna take a few years. But when that day comes I'll be ready...! His grin -- when it happens -- is like the sun suddenly breaking through the clouds. 60's MUSIC KICKS IN.

dialogues.speaker: D32
dialogues.text: Green Revision 10-14-13 20.

dialogues.speaker: IN A CAVERNOUS HALL, (60'S ROCK MUSIC CONT.)
dialogues.text: Bobby defeats several opponents. He poses among other Eas European grandmasters. Carmine is nearby, beaming.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSREEL ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: (in Yugoslav; subtitled) In Portoroz, Yugoslavia, American chess prodigy Bobby Fischer became the youngest ever Grandmaster in the history of the game... Bobby has a large gold medal around his neck. An American news reporter puts a large microphone in his face.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: How do you explain your success? Bobby looks at him for a moment, then simply, without gui

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I'm better than everybody else.

dialogues.speaker: IN A CHESS CLUB B32
dialogues.text: Bobby plays TWENTY OPPONENTS at once -- their chessboards surrounding him in a circle. Carmine hovers nearby.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSREEL ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: With each passing year he rises in the International ranking. Maybe someday America can finally claim a champion of its own. As he moves from one to another, we INTERCUT MORE ARCHIVA FOOTAGE: JFK'S funeral. The Beatles. The Berlin Wall. Vietnam. LBJ. Cassius Clay. The CAMERA spins with him as he plays -- faster and faste until, as Bobby passes from our view, obscured behind one player, he EMERGES on the other side as the mature 24 yea old we saw in the opening scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caption: Olympiad of Varna, Bulgaria'62

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby and Carmine walking. Bobby is psyching himself up.  32 Green Revision 10-14-13 20A.

dialogues.speaker: CARMINE
dialogues.text: Okay, Ivanovich relies on the Indian defense--

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: He stopped using it in Portorosz. And Petrossian is no longer defensive out of the Nimzo. His mother died last month and he's become more cautious. He FH HK

dialogues.speaker: CARMINE
dialogues.text: How do you know this stuff?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: The magazines, man. They don't know I read Russian. All I gotta do is outscore them by two points. That way they gotta give me shot at the championship.

dialogues.speaker: CARMINE
dialogues.text: Good. Good. How about we think about the first one first...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The enforced stillness of a chess tournament. Bobby defea one opponent after another. He looks invincible. His focu is absolute.  Yellow Revision 10-11-13 21. Nearby, two RUSSIAN PLAYERS have finished their game -- they're shaking hands. A draw. Bobby looks over, studying their board. Suddenly he stand up from his game and approaches an ARBITER.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (whispering) Excuse me. Over there -- the Russians -- TBD has an opening on Petrosian, instead he draws in fourteen moves?

dialogues.speaker: ARBITER
dialogues.text: If you'll take your seat please, Mr. Fischer.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Are you blind? They're playing each other soft to save their strength and then padding their point totals so I can't win -- YOU SHOULD BE

dialogues.speaker: WATCHING THIS
dialogues.text: HEADS TURN as he voice rises. Carmine comes over.

dialogues.speaker: CARMINE
dialogues.text: Bobby, sit down, you don't want to be disqualified.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: You see what they're up to? No matter how many points I get, they're getting more. This is such bullshit... Then, into the hall, walks Boris Spassky! Bobby can't hel but stare as Spassky sits at a nearby table. Bobby tries to return to his game, but he's upset now. He furtively steals glances at the handsome Grandmaster. Suddenly, everything is distracting to him. A chair SCRAPING. A light buzzes. A Russian advisor WHISPERING to another advisor. Bobby looks up at the TOURNAMENT BOARD. _He scheduled to play Spassky next. Bobby crackles with anxiety -- looking over at Spassky -- while his opponent ploddingly contemplates his next move. Finally, unable to stand it:  33 Yellow Revision 10-11-13 21A.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ..-Knight to Kings Pawn Six, Bishop to Bk4, King to e-5, Queen to Qp2. King to Nb6, Queen to Bd3. Mate. His opponent realizes he is indeed doomed.

dialogues.speaker: DOC-STYLE
dialogues.text: The door opens and Bobby storms out. A cameraman films hi

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: They're conspiring against me. They want to destroy me because they know I'm better than they are. Bobby is followed by officials and journalists. takes his arm.

dialogues.speaker: CARMINE
dialogues.text: Bobby... Bobby yanks his arm free...

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: The Russians are cheating! There, I've said it! Nobody else will! Bobby grabs a guy with Soviet accreditation. Carmine  Yellow Revision 10-11-13 22.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You want that in Russian? Niet pycni osmahbi. An OFFICIAL takes Bobby's arm...

dialogues.speaker: OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: Mr Fischer, if we could go back inside and talk about this... Bobby pushes the official -- who falls into a signboard. Bobby tries to help the man to his feet. Silence. Then Bobby grabs a chair, stands on it.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Okay, I want to make a statement... First I'd like to apologize for pushing that guy. ...You're okay?

dialogues.speaker: OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: Something to tell my grandchildren. As Bobby continues we hear WHISPERED TRANSLATIONS.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I came here to take part in this tournament, which is my right as American champion. But it is obvious this whole thing has been fixed by the Russkies. Carmine rolls his eyes. Murmurs around the audience.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They arrange draws so they can save their strength for the late rounds. But the corrupt Federation does nothing to stop it. I've been waiting ten years to get a shot at the championship...and I'm sick of it. (working himself up) As a result, I am -- as of right now -- now-this-second, quitting.

dialogues.speaker: CARMINE
dialogues.text: Oh, man...

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I won't play against fuckin' Commie cheaters who hate me and hate America. Bobby sees a radio microphone poking out from the crowd.  Yellow Revision 10-11-13 23.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sorry about 'fucks' in there... but anyway....screw you all. In fact I'm retiring from chess forever. Bobby kicks over the chair as he gets down and walks away

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carmine tries to keep up with Bobby as he marches away.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I'm the best in the world and they know it and they stole it from me! The whole system is rigged...

dialogues.speaker: CARMINE
dialogues.text: Bobby... Bobby, wait-- (catches up to him) ...It's okay to be nervous about playing him.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: CARMINE
dialogues.text: Spassky. You saw he was next and you quit. Spassky is exiting with his handlers, looking cool, confi

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: You're fulla shit. It has nothing to do with Spassky! It's statistically impossible for me to win now.

dialogues.speaker: CARMINE
dialogues.text: First rule of chess. Always someone better than you.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Better than you, maybe. He strides away, leaving Carmine behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kitchen is a disaster. Old take-out containers and di coffee cups. Chess boards, each with a game-in-progress.  Green Revision 10-14-13 24.%* Bobby is asleep, his head on a chessboard. It looks like lives in his bathrobe. A key in the doorway. Joan enters; with her is her seven-year-old GIRL. Bobby wakes up.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Hey, Baby boy...

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Didn't know you had a key.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: (to her daughter) Say hello to your Uncle. The girl shyly mumbles a hello.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: You like chess, Lizzie? This is the rook. See the castle on top, like in a fairy story, right? It moves like this. And this is the knight, you like horses...? Meanwhile Joan is subtly cleaning up.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: So...what've you been up to?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: The usual.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Getting out much?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Too busy. (to Elizabeth) --Here, you try it.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: .+-Doing what?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Working on my game! I've developed files this thick on Tal, on Petrossian, on Fila... I'm working fourteen hours a day.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: So you didn't quit.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (a bit overheated) I'll play when the Russians stop fixing the Candidates tournament!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ee ee  Green Revision 10-14-13 24a.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: I know, baby. I know... She produces a comb and begins to comb his hair. He close his eyes to a tenderness he rarely gives in to.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So I bumped into an old friend from school... She saw your picture in the New York Times magazine.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I was in the New York Times?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: The piece about you punching a guy. From the picture, she thinks you're a looker. (smooths Bobby's hair) I don't see it, you know? But the point is...you have a date.  25. Bobby opens his eyes. Joan smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sixties rock-and-roll on the juke box. A sweet-faced youn girl, MARIA, is waiting. She looks nervous as Bobby enter

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Maria?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Bobby?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: My sister told me not to scare you. He smiles. Sits.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Boo. Are you a virgin too? Maria almost chokes on her coffee.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don't much care, you know? I don't know why there's even a word for it. There's no word for people who've never flown in a plane or... Maria looks a little thrown...

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you ever make up words for things there's no word for?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I...no, I really don't.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Am I scaring you by the way?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: No... A little. Maria is beginning to get up to speed with Bobby's crazin She's unnerved but drawn to his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm Italian. Bobby doesn't respond.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Joan said you've been to Rome to play chess.  26.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (vapid fire) It has two hundred and thirty five statues of people who look like they're still in bed.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: (laughing) Did you count them?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Are you interested in politics?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I'm a Republican actually.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Right there, that's why you're a virgin. Republicans only have sex to have babies. Democrats have sex because they can't help themselves. Maria laughs again. Bobby is puzzled by her laughter. He arranges the sugar cubes with his long fingers...

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Are you going to eat something? Bobby puts a sugar cube into his mouth. Peers at her.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Do you play chess?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Good. Maria takes a breath, decides to be bold.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Joan said you've quit traveling all over to tournaments and maybe you'd like to start doing regular things. Maria thinks maybe she is one of the regular things he mi do. He smiles then peers at Maria's face. After a moment.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Beautiful. He stares at her face. Maria reacts...blushing a little. Then...still staring at her face...he speaks fast and eve  37 Pink Revision 10-01-13 27.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Capablanca versus Emanuel Lasker, Havana, 1921, endgame. The White King was here... Bobby touches the tip of Maria's nose...

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Black King here. He touches her chin. As Bobby names different chess piece he gently touches her eyes, her cheeks, her ears, placing each piece as if Maria's face were a chessboard...

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: White Knight, black pawn, white rook, black Bishop to your chin-- Maria has closed her eyes, his touch is gentle.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: --your ear to your nose and taking out an eye for a cheek bone. Move this here. This here... A pause. Bobby stares at her face and looks troubled...

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Beautiful like a Picasso. Maria opens her eyes -- overwhelmed by his gentle physica

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You believe in love.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Uh...

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: That's what I thought. (stands; sighs) Sorry, Joan. He grabs his coat and leaves. She sits there, forlorn.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: It's Maria.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hunched Bobby walks fast along the busy Brooklyn sidewa and ducks into the store, like someone entering a Porn sh More SURVEILLANCE SHOTS of him from across the street.  Yellow Revision 10-11-13 28.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby enters, looking wired. The Bookstore Owner speaks softly in Russian...

dialogues.speaker: BOOKSTORE OWNER
dialogues.text: Good evening 'Bobby Grandmaster'. You couldn't sleep?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Would you please speak to me in American?

dialogues.speaker: BOOKSTORE OWNER
dialogues.text: So why have you gone to the trouble of learning our language?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (in Russian) Okay. Fine. Is it here yet?

dialogues.speaker: BOOKSTORE OWNER
dialogues.text: (back to English) Let me see... It is the TBD you buy, yes? Published by the Moscow Chess Federation. The Owner's WIFE drifts by behind the counter.

dialogues.speaker: OWNER'S WIFE
dialogues.text: Ah. The American boy who hates us but can't resist our magazines.

dialogues.speaker: BOOKSTORE OWNER
dialogues.text: The October edition is just in. Bobby finds the magazine in the rack.

dialogues.speaker: BOOKSTORE OWNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Page six. (twisting the knife) He is becoming the new Messiah. A photo of SPASSKY. The caption reads: 'World Champion Bo Spassky wins tenth Blitz tournament.' Once again, Bobby's steel-trap of a mind memorizes each move at lighting spee

dialogues.speaker: BOOKSTORE OWNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They say he won't ever lose a match. Bobby pays him. The owner hands him a card.

dialogues.speaker: BOOKSTORE OWNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Someone left this for you. A lawyer. You are in trouble, maybe?  Pink Revision 10-01-13 28A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An anonymous FIGURE sits behind a desk as a sheaf of SURVEILLANCE PHOTOS are shown to him. We SEE Bobby enteri the Russian bookstore.  39 Green Revision 10-14-13 29.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patchy snow. Empty apart from Bobby, who sits before an empty chessboard playing a game with invisible pieces. A GUY in an overcoat approaches. It is MARSHALL.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: You want a game?

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: What? You think I'm stupid?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: You know who I am.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know who you are. Been trying to reach you. (hands him a card) You don't answer your phone.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: You're the lawyer. What'd I do...?

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Nothing. You did nothing. You do nothing. That's why I'm here. Marshall hands him an article torn from Sports Illustrate ‘The Russians Have Fixed World Chess, 'By Bobby Fischer.'

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You were angry. ee ee  Green Revision 10-14-13 30.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: That was years ago.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Are you still angry? Bobby rocks back and forth a little.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I mean, are you political, Bobby?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Like a rock. Like a baseball bat.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: You told the truth about the Russians.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Sometimes the truth is a hand grenade. (almost coy) I just made that up by the way. Marshall produces a chess magazine, drops it on the table

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: There's been an announcement. (reads) ‘Soviet invasion to hit California Surf. Greatest chess player who ever lived to visit U.S.'.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Yeah. They're coming to California to play in The Piatigorsky.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: They say it's just a game, for fun, hand of friendship, all that crap. But you know the truth... They're using chess to say 'screw America’.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, America is soft. (re the empty tables) A little bit of weather and I'm all alone here.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: The Russians laugh at us. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Green Revision 10-14-13

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They know there's not one single American can beat a single Russian. Their chess mastery proves to the world Soviet intellectual superiority over the decadent West.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Seriously man, who the hell are you?

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: I'm just a fan. I love creative people. I also love my country. I also love to make money. (leans in) I want to represent you. Exhibitions. Endorsements. Serious money. Otherwise I wouldn't be out here freezing my ass off. Bobby laughs in a cloud of breath.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're the one man in this country who can put up a fight, maybe even beat them. And I want a front row seat when the good guys win.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: You don't know if I can still play.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: I talk to people. The cafe on Clinton Street. The bookstore... You hate to lose, Bobby. If you weren't beating the magazines you wouldn't keep buying them. Bobby studies Marshall, who turns to a picture of

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Carmine thinks you're afraid of him. Yeah, he's going to have some fun over here...

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Hey, screw him. Screw Boris Spassky. He taps his temple with his long finger.

dialogues.speaker: 31-31A.
dialogues.text: Spassky. ee ee

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 40 4l Green Revision 10-14-13

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have moves in my brain like bullets. I ran all his games and I know how he thinks.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Yeah. Bang-bang. Patzers in Washington Square. So what?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: He has a life. He has a wife. (brushes away dead leaves from the board) All I have is this. That's why I can beat him.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: If you don't play, you don't win. Buif you win, you make history. Bobby looks at him, a wicked smile spreading across his f

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: When I win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Manhattan Club is nicer than its Brooklyn equivalent. Marshall walks through with A PRIEST in long black robes enters. This is FATHER LOMBARDY.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: He's been preparing for six hours.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: I'm just a selector. I hope he realizes it's a committee that decides who plays.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: You're a grandmaster. He respects you. You're the only one who ever beat Spassky.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: We were kids. He'd destroy me now.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: And you've beaten Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: When he was twelve. And a bad loser. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 40 41  Green Revision 10-14-13 32A.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Said the room was too loud, the lamp was too bright. He's a pain in the ass.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: He asked for you. Wants you to be his second. Marshall hands Lombardy a letter.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's a letter of explanation and apology to the Federation.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: With the f word in the first line.  Green Revision 10-14-13 33.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: He's nursed a grudge a long time. He's studied how the Russians play...every day, eighteen hours a day for four years. For him, Vietnam and the Beatles never happened.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: I'm guessing he still has his opinions about the Soviets?

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: You'll promise the committee we'll keep him out of trouble...

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: The Piatigorsky has been organized to build bridges, not burn them.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: So we lose twelve to zero and that's a bridge.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: I heard he has mental health problems.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: So did Mozart.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: What if we get him there and he cracks...

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Bobby won't crack. He will explode.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marshall ushers Lombardy in. Bobby is dressed to kill.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Bobby? Father Lombardy's here...

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: How ya doing, Bobby?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Against Petrosian in Zurich in the third game you shouldn't have sacrificed your King's pawn. That's the thing that got ya. Father Lombardy rocks back a little...  Yellow Revision 10-11-13 34.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You always play too cautiously but then you go crazy in the other direction. It's a bad weakness. They peer at each other.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, if I criticize a priest, do I go to hell?

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: ..-Depends if you believe in God.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (nods appreciatively) Good move. He gestures at the chessboards lined up before them.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm going to show you how you could've won in thirteen moves.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: Not possible. Several tables have been laid out in advance.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Okay, here's where you screwed up. You got greedy and traded knight for bishop, sacrificed your pawn. But what if you'd done this... He puts the pieces back on the board with an arrogant sla

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: See, the Russians are like boa constrictors. If you do nothing, they strangle you to death, but if you confuse him, attack him everywhere... Bobby moves rapidly. Pieces moving, trading.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: First my machine guns attack his king. BAM! BAM! BAM! BAM! All he can do is defend himself-- Five more moves. Check. Check. He takes a rook.  Pink Revision 10-01-13 34a.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: You understand, Bobby, this tournament is about diplomacy. Bobby ignores him, moves to the next table.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I want five hundred dollars for each game. I want to buy my sister something for her new baby.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: I heard you were taking medication.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: My sister sent me to a doctor who put me on something but I started playing as badly as you. So I stopped. He makes three more tactical moves.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now we've got him on the run.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: What about Rook takes Bishop?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Of course. The smoke clears. He thinks he's safe... But there's a plot to kill the king, an assassin is waiting, forgotten in the background. Lombardy is entranced.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You see the Russian Queen, standing there, so high and mighty? She thinks she can protect him. Bobby goes to the next table, making several quick moves-

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: uddenly the assassin comes to life! The King tries to escape. But now the hunt is on--!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He makes a few furious final moves, trapping the white Ki

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Even his beloved Queen can't save him. The King is defenseless. The King is dead.  43 Pink Revision 10-01-13 35. The Kind Falls

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: Holy shit.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I didn't know priests used bad language... (to Marshall) I like this guy. (to Lombardy) Father? Take the crazy kid to California.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beach Boys harmonies. ARCHIVAL FOOTAGE & MOCK-DOC: Waves crash on a sun-drenche beach. The surf is up. Long boards and polka-dot bikinis. Four black limos pull up beside the beach. Caption: Santa Monica, California, June 1966. KGB men in dark suits and shades emerge. Out of the rear doors step TEN less well-built men, also in dark suits. T SOVIET CHESS TEAM steps hesitantly onto the sand.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO DJ, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: This is 93 KHJ, Los Angeles...  44 45 Yellow Revision 10-11-13 36. The KGB men watch the grand masters stroll self-conscious on the beach. A few SURVEILLANCE SHOTS.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO DJ, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Don't be fooled by the warm weather because the Cold War just blew into town. The Soviet chess team arrived in LA for a good-will tournament. BORIS SPASSKY lights a cigarette. He is trim, athletic. H wears dark shades, hair brushed back. An impressive figur

dialogues.speaker: RADIO DJ, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: With them is the current world champion, Boris Spassky, said to be the best chess player who ever lived. Spassky takes off his shades and rubs his eyes against th bright light. We sense a certain weariness...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fleet of limos cruise up the palm-fringed courtyard. The doormen jump to attention. Photographers take photos.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO DJ, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The comrades are booked into the Beverly Hills Hilton Hotel. So much for working class values... Boris is hurried inside by two KGB men.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO DJ, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: If you're listening guys, welcome to the free world and enjoy the sunshine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the seedy parking lot, a couple of hookers are smoking A taxi pulls in. Lombardy, Marshall and Bobby emerge. Bobby looks at the seedy Motel, shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Right.  Green Revision 10-14-13 37.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lombardy and Marshall are checking in while Bobby paces. checks out the mural of Santa Monica, observes passing ki

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: ..-Really hot in here... What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: MOTEL CLERK
dialogues.text: Repair guy didn't show.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (to Marshall) You said a hotel, not some roach coach that rents by the hour.

dialogues.speaker: MOTEL CLERK
dialogues.text: You a rock star? (to Marshall) Acts like a rock star.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: You know what? I ain't staying here. Bobby turns and walks out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby emerges with Lombardy and Marshall in pursuit.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: You said, “improved accomodations."

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: This is improved. Somebody else is paying for it.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Where are the Russians staying? Lombardy and Marshall exchange a look. 46 47  Green Revision 10-14-13

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: We don't have their kind of money.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Money?! We invented money --

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: We rely on private donors.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: So find some rich ones! (shakes his head) The Russians get whatever they want because their government understands what it takes to win. Chess is a national priority! They don't put chess players next to Route 66! (looks at the traffic) All I want is some QUIET!! One of the hookers speaks up out of nowhere...

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: So stop yelling. Bobby looks up. She's attractive, if somewhat... obvious.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: You're right. Sorry. What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Donna.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: See ya later, Donna. I'm going for a walk.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Want some company?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Sure. He sets off toward the ocean. Donna hurries to catch up. Lombardy turns to Marshall

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: And he hasn't even started playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 48 Yellow Revision 10-11-13 38A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The suite is vast. A shower is running A note in English and Russian: 'The Beverly Hills Hilton Hotel welcomes Mr Boris Spassky....Chess Champion of the World'. Along with his dark suit, Boris has packed a Hawaiian shi A small crucifix hangs inside his open suitcase. On a tab a chessboard with the pieces set for a new game. Boris emerges, drying himself. Then the door opens. An adviser enters. This is GELLER. He carries a folder. Their conversation is in Russian with ENGLISH SUBTITLES.

dialogues.speaker: BORIS
dialogues.text: You don't knock?

dialogues.speaker: GELLER
dialogues.text: You didn't hear me. Geller immediately turns off the radio jazz.  Green Revision 10-14-13 39.

dialogues.speaker: BORIS
dialogues.text: It is interfering with your listening devices?

dialogues.speaker: GELLER
dialogues.text: (smiling) Now you are being paranoid. Geller goes to the window, looks down.

dialogues.speaker: GELLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I came in here because there is a better view. Come and see. There is a black goddess lying by the pool and you can see right up her crotch. This is a great country, yeah? (peers at him, again:) I said this is a great country, yes? Boris doesn't respond. Geller tosses a folder onto the be

dialogues.speaker: GELLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The American team. There is someone on this list I hoped was dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby is walking in his sharp suit, the waves drenching h shoes. He is walking with purpose, mumbling, lost in a ga being played in his head. Then we see Donna trailing behind, high heels in hand.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: This is all you wanted to do? Bobby has spaced out for a moment. He snaps back.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Huh? Collect shells if you want.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: You walk pretty fast. Bobby stops, sits down on the sand and stares out to sea.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Maybe I'll sleep here instead. Donna sits down heavily beside Bobby and lights a cigaret

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So what do you do, Donna? Donna looks quizzically at Bobby.  Green Revision 10-14-13 40-42.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I fuck people.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Yeah? So do I. (pondering) ..-Listen, after I've won this chess thing I was thinking maybe I'd get rid of my virginity. It's getting stupid, you know--?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: ...-You've never had sex?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Not with someone else, no.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I'll make you an introductory offer. 300 bucks.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Two hundred.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Two-fifty.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Two twenty-five. And if I win I get the next one for free.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: You really represent America?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Hell, yeah. I represent America.  50 51 52 53 Yellow Revision 10-11-13 43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Soviet chess team climb into their fleet of Limos. Bo appears to have two KGB guards allocated just to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Bobby is getting dressed, he and Lombardy play "blind" chess. The board, the pieces, it's all in their heads. 50 51 52 53  Green Revision 10-14-13 43A.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Bishop to Queen 3.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: Bishop to Knight 5.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Knight to King Knight 5.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: King Rook to Queen 1. Each moves elicits a reaction. Delight or dread.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Queen to Knight 4. Ha!

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: You sonofabitch.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (grinning) Not me. Morphy vs. Anderssen. Lombardy's competitive instincts are emerging.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: Bishop to Bishop 1.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: King Rook to Kl.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: Pawn to Queen Rook 4.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Queen to King 7.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: Queen takes Queen.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Rook takes Queen. Lombardy studies the board in his head.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: seeee Shit. Bobby just smiles. Marshall knocks and enters.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: You ready? He hands Bobby a three-page stapled mimeo.  Green Revision 10-14-13 43B.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Background on the Soviet and Cuban teams.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Are you kidding? The Russians have a folder this thick on me. They've been studying me since I was twelve. He tears it up, turns to check himself out in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They're sitting by the pool in their fancy hotel, having drinks, laughing. (squares his tie) We'll see who's laughing tonight. He starts for the door.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You coming? Bobby leaves. Lombardy smiles at Marshall.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: I think he's ready.  54 55 Green Revision 10-14-13 44.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Soviet flag and the Stars and Stripes hang above a ha

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Players, audience and journalists wait for the matches to begin. The Russians receive last minute briefings. Lombar is pouring coffee as Marshall enters, frantic.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: He's not anywhere! If he's not seated in four minutes, he forfeits.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: He'll be there.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: A little prayer wouldn't hurt.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: I pray for his opponent. Marshall shakes his head and hurries away.  56 Green Revision 10-14-13 45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marshall enters and begins to check the cubicles.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Bobby? You here?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: In here. Marshall finds Bobby fully clothed, sitting on the toilet busily writing on a scrap of paper.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: What the hell? You've go to take your seat! Bobby gets to his feet, handing Marshall the note.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I had to find somewhere quiet. I want you to give this to her...

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: To who?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: My mom. Bobby gives him the letter. For a moment we glimpse the fragile little boy inside Bobby. He goes to wash his hand

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She lives in California now. She'll be here.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Bobby, you've drawn Ivanovich in the first round.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Whatever you do, don't let her watch me. She'll screw up my game. Just stop her and give her the letter (dries his hands) I've told her to follow on the radio.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Bobby, Ivanovich is officially the third best chess player in the world. Bobby's little boy look is replaced by a roguish grin. 56  57 58 59 Green Revision 10-14-13 46.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Fourth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A chessboard. A clock TICKS. An empty chair with Bobby's name on it. Russian Grandmaster IVANOVICH sits opposite. An adviser whispers in his ear. Lombardy checks his watch

dialogues.speaker: REFEREE
dialogues.text: If he is not here in sixty seconds the game will be forfeited. Ivanovich folds his arms and waits. A door at the far end of the room OPENS. Bobby saunters i His casual attitude immediately wrong-foots his opponent. ripple of APPLAUSE as he raises one hand in acknowledgeme An official hands Bobby his "move" card.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (patting his pockets; to Lombardy) Gotta pen? Lombardy hands him a pen. Bobby sits and waits for the cl to run down some more, staring directly at Ivanovich. Ten seconds left on the clock. Ivanovich begins to wilt a little. Bobby smiles a devilish smile and whispers...

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ten, nine, eight, seven, six, five, four, three...two... Bobby SLAPS his first move, then SLAPS his clock just as hard. His eyes never leave Ivanovich's face.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SANTA MONICA TOURNAMENT HALL, NIGHT
dialogues.text: The Limos are waiting. The auditorium doors open and Ivanovich appears, escorted the Soviet team advisor, LIVO NEI, who hurries him into o of the waiting cars. Ivanovich has his head bowed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The limo pulls away. Ivanovich sits beside Nei, staring straight ahead. They speak Russian with ENGLISH subtitles 57 58 59  60 61 Yellow Revision 10-11-13 47.

dialogues.speaker: IVANOVICH
dialogues.text: It was like... having a building fall on me.

dialogues.speaker: NEI
dialogues.text: When we get to the hotel the team doctor will give you a thorough examination. (looks at him) You lost because you have the flu. You probably caught it on the flight.

dialogues.speaker: IVANOVICH
dialogues.text: Yes. I do have a headache.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain drenches the parking lot. Bobby is on the pay phone, wired. Donna appears out of one of the rooms.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Hey, heard you won... Congrats! (watches him) What's wrong with the phone in your room?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I heard this click, click. Our phone was always bugged growing up. (dialing) Some family, huh? My mom is bugged by us, I'm bugged by the Russians.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Who you calling?  62 Green Revision 10-14-13 48.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (on the phone) Operator, I'm trying to find a number for Regina Fischer....well how many * Regina Fischers can there be in California?.... (to Donna) Making sure my mom doesn't come * tomorrow. * (on the phone) Somewhere near the beach.... (to Donna) She likes the ocean. (on the phone) Well ask the lady next to you and she can ask the lady next to her. You sit in lines, right? Donna stifles a giggle.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just look her up in your-- He's cut off. *

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shit. *

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: So you want to lose your virginity tonight?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Donna, I haven't forgotten our arrangement and I'm looking forward to it. (smiles) But tonight I've got to practice. I killed one of them today so tomorrow they'll come at me like wasps. Bobby turns and walks off into the rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby and Lombardy are playing "blitz." Speed chess. Lombardy is pushing Bobby. Bobby pushes back.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Passed up having sex for this. WHAP. Hits the clock. WHAP. Lombardy makes a counter-move

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: Passed it up for twenty years.  63 Yellow Revision 10-11-13 48a.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby's is the only light still on. From inside, we HEAR WHAP, WHAP, WHAP as their practice continues into the nig 63  Green Revision 10-14-13 49.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KGB guys flirt with American women. A SHADOW slips past. It's Boris Spassky making his escape

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boris wanders through residential Beverly Hills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boris is playing a pinball machine inside a sandwich shop Geller peering in from the street, spots him and enters.

dialogues.speaker: GELLER
dialogues.text: Been looking for you. Boris keeps playing.

dialogues.speaker: GELLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You have a game tomorrow. You should be sleeping. Outside, a limo pulls up and a KGB man gets out. Geller n through the window that everything is all right.

dialogues.speaker: GELLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Disappearing makes people nervous.

dialogues.speaker: BORIS
dialogues.text: Is Ivanovich really sick?

dialogues.speaker: GELLER
dialogues.text: Influenza. We are flying him home. Boris looks at him, knows he's lying. Goes back to his ga

dialogues.speaker: GELLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It looks bad to lose even one game to an American. Boris allows the ball to drop out of play.  67 Green Revision 10-14-13 50.

dialogues.speaker: GELLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If Fischer makes it to the final you will be there to crush him. The CLICK of a SURVEILLANCE SHOT from across the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marshall walks out. Lombardy takes him aside.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: We have a problem. Bobby is standing by the empty pool, holding a sheet of p

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I'm not going to play again until my conditions are met.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: What conditions?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Number one. From now on we arrive at tournaments in a big black car like the Russians.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Limousines cost money.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Number two. My picture was on today's front page of the LA Times. The more I win, the more people come. A thousand people are paying 5 dollars apiece to see me play. That's $5,000. I want 30%. $1,500.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Bobby--

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Money is respect. Chess is a sport. People respect sports stars. (reading) Number three. I need five feet between me and the audience. I can smell their breath, it's almost like I hear their thoughts. My thoughts need to be on the board.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Is that all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Green Revision 10-14-13

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: And get somebody to check our phones aren't being bugged. (starts off) Screw the limo. I'm walking. 50A.  Green Revision 10-14-13 51. Bobby sets off. Lombardy sets off after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lombardy catches up to him.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: You ready to talk about the match now?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (grins) Forgive me, father, for I have sinned.. Lombardy can't help but smile. Bobby can be disarming.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: Yeah, right. Now....if Benko plays the Sicilian, what's your counter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can no longer HEAR them as they walk away but their animated gestures signal the intensity of their preparati

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The motel clerk is watching local news on a small TV.

dialogues.speaker: NEWS ANCHOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Americans don't beat Russians at chess. But it happened today in Santa Monica-- INTERCUT DOC-STYLE "news" footage of Bobby's victories -- masterful, slapping his pieces, scribbling in his noteboo

dialogues.speaker: NEWS ANCHOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: --and when American chess sensation Bobby Fischer is around, it just keeps on happening.... Donna and the motel clerk are watching on the tiny TV.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Son of a bitch broke three of my phones looking for bugs.  69 Green Revision 10-14-13 52.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: That's what rock stars do. They trash hotel rooms.

dialogues.speaker: NEWS ANCHOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Tomorrow, a record crowd will watch the American -- Bobby Fischer -- as he faces Russian World Champion Boris Spassky in the final match. Donna stares at the screen, wide-eyed.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Never fucked a champion before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby lies in bed, lost in thought. Donna is beside him.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Wasn't so bad was it?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: wanes See, the problem is I'm black...

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I like to open with the Kings Indian but he's an expert on the Samisch.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Who? *

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Spassky. So maybe a Grunfeld... * But then I need to find a remedy to * P-B4... He spins inward. She's feeling a little left out. *

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: .+..Did you reach your Mom? Bet * she'd be proud. She tries stroking his arm. He withdraws slightly. *

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Gotta go back to work. Bobby is already pulling on his pants, leaving the room.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Yeah, it was good for me, too.  70 71 Green Revision 10-14-13 52a.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby can't sleep. Paces. Studies his notebook. It's 1:00am.Bobby drinks milk. Paces. Studies more. It's 3:30a He's about to drift off. The alarm clock RINGS. 7:00am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby and Lombardy walk a hallway. Bobby looks like hell.  Green Revision 10-14-13 53.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: Up late, huh? You all right? Their eyes meet for a flicker.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Never better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby stops before entering the playing area and sees Spa Boris looks rested and detached. Lombardy sees him lookin

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: You got this guy.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Think I don't know that? Across the hall, Boris senses Bobby's gaze. Their eyes me We sense the two men have made fatal contact, and one of them must be destroyed. Bobby looks away first. Bobby and Spassky approach their table. The audience APPL The two men stand behind their seats. Geller whispers in Boris's ear. Livo Nei hands him a note pad and pen. A thi brings him a worksheet, a fourth hands him a glass of wat Lombardy leans in to whisper to Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: Remember, don't try to overpress. If he opens with the Nimzo--

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (harsh whisper) You think I'm a idiot!?! Lombardy is mortified. Bobby is immediately contrite.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...Sorry, Father.  73 74 Green Revision 10-14-13 54. He looks up to see if Boris has heard him. Boris steps forward, extending his hand. Bobby hesitates and the flic of hesitation is caught by Spassky. Finally they shake. Boris sits down calmly as Bobby drops into his chair. Bobby is distracted by THE SOUND of a chair scraping. His eyes dart to it. He looks back -- only to realize Boris has been watching the whole time. Bobby tries to stare at him. Boris smiles He has already won.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door SLAMS open and Bobby bursts through. His fury te all. He has lost. Lombardy and Marshall hurry to catch up

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: Bobby, you beat three Russians.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: They're waiting to give you the runners-up medal.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: A medal for losing?

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: No one expected you to beat Spassky.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: She wasn't here, was she?

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Who? He doesn't wait for an answer and walks off toward the be

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: At least talk to the TV people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby trudges in the sand. Tears well as he collapses lik a disconsolate child. He has lost. His carefully-cultivat illusion of invincibility is shattered, revealed for what is, a cloak for the vast, untouchable hole in his heart. He idly draws a chessboard in the wet sand -- torturing himself with memories of losing.  75 Green Revision 10-14-13 55. A wave rolls in, washing out his drawing. He sits there, water pooling around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lombardy sits on the bed. Marshall enters.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: He's disappeared. He pours himself a drink.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: He'll be back.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: How can you be so sure?

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: It's all that matters to him. Without chess, he doesn't exist.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: You think he can ever beat Spassky? Lombardy nurses his drink, non-committal.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hypothetically, what would it take to make him world champion?

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: (stares at him) The desk clerk asked why we're making so many calls to DC. I didn't call DC. Who have you been talking to--?

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
