dialogues.text: There are people...in high places... who take an interest in any confrontation between us and the Soviet Union.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: The state department? (no answer) The CIA? (no answer) The WHITE HOUSE?

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Bobby wants limos? He gets limos. And they'1l1 throw in 'honorariums' for each victory.  Green Revision 10-14-13

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: Paid for by who? Marshall stares back at him.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Are you a patriot, father?

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: Mostly.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Bobby may be a little off but he understands this whole thing better than you. (looks at him) We're at war. Only it's not being fought by guns and missiles -- not yet at least -- it's a war of perception. The poor kid from Brooklyn taking on the whole Soviet Empire. The perfect American story.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: (starts to laugh) Which means you're out schnorring right wing anti-Communist money people? This wouldn't possibly be helpful to the Nixon White House?

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: ...-There's such a thing as doing well by doing good. And you haven't answered my question... Lombardy takes a sip of whiskey.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: Bobby Fischer is the second best chess player I have ever seen. He also has severe problems in his head.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Which need to be understood and managed.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: Managed? Bobby? (shakes his head) Ever heard of Paul Morphy? 1855. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Green Revision 10-14-13 57.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Greatest player this country ever had -- before Bobby, that is. By 21 he'd beaten every master in Europe. Liked to play ten people at a time. Blindfolded. Then things got a little weird. Started having "visions," became convinced people were trying to poison him. Quit at 26 and eventually killed himself in the bathtub surrounded by twelve pairs of ladies' shoes. Lombardy takes another sip.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This game is a rabbit hole. After only four moves there are more than three hundred billion options to consider, more forty-move games than the number of stars in the galaxy, more openings, defenses, gambits than there are atoms in the universe. (remembering) It can bring you very close to the edge. I've been there. When I was twenty-three, I--

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Nice story, father. With respect, my question was about Bobby. Could he win? Lombardy glares at him.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: If Bobby went for the title it would mean traveling around the world playing interzonals for three years... That's three years in much worse places than this one. (finishes his whiskey) In my opinion he might not make it that long. Marshall stands up, taking the bottle with him.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: It's your job to see that he does. If we ever find him.  76

dialogues.speaker: A77
dialogues.text: Pink Revision 10-01-13 58.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby has slept on the beach. His clothes are rumpled and his hair is wild. As he sits up he sees an odd sight. A hundred yards down the beach, a big black limo has disg three MEN. Two are KGB. The third is wearing a Beverly Hi hotel bathrobe. It's Boris Spassky, come for his morning swim. The KGB men carry his clothes. Bobby watches, fascinated, as Boris shrugs off his bathro and begins an exercise regime. Bobby gets to his knees as Boris walks into the ocean and begins to swim. The KGB gu smoke cigarettes, waiting for Boris to finish. As Boris steps out of the ocean, a KGB guy holds out a to for him. Bobby leaps to his feet and yells...

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Hey!! Asshole!! They're not bodyguards, they're jailers!! They've got your brain. They're inside your mind! They wouldn't even let you kill yourself if you wanted!! Boris looks up as Bobby yells, but he is far away and loo like a bum, so he doesn't immediately recognize him...

dialogues.speaker: KGB GUY
dialogues.text: Just some drunk sleeping it off. America is full of them. Bobby, meanwhile, is laughing to himself. He steps into t ocean, fully clothed, and begins to splash around...

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Look at me man, I'm free! He jumps into the waves and begins to play. Boris stares slowly realizes it's Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm coming for you, man!! Better get ready -- 'cause I'M...COMING!! The KGB minders quickly hustle Boris away, but not before looks back to see Bobby take a sardonic bow. We might notice something new in Boris's eyes when he rea that Bobby has recovered from the loss. He is unnerved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lomonosov Moscow University Dormitories, February 1967.  77 78 79 80 Green Revision 10-14-13 59.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man answers the door. A postman hands him a Russian Magazine. The cover features a photograph of Bobby. We mi notice he has large feet inside his ragged tartan slipper

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cyril hands the magazine to Regina. Bobby is on the cover

dialogues.speaker: CYRIL
dialogues.text: He is officially entering the race to become world champion. Regina nods, walks away toward the bedroom with the magaz

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When she enters, WE SEE walls covered in clippings and photographs of Bobby: headlines from the NY Times, LA Tim London Times and Pravda. Covers from Life and Time magazi We PAN past articles proclaiming his triumphs. (Fischer dominates at Skopje). 70's hard rock kicks in.

dialogues.speaker: DOC-STYLE
dialogues.text: Bobby is being interviewed.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: ...-The Russians are afraid of me, man. They've avoided me for years. (a big grin) They can run but they can't hide! A scrum of reporters bears down on him.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Bobby, you're the first American ever to reach the interzonal semis. How does it feel? Are you afraid? Bobby freezes. He stares at all the people yelling at him

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I have nothing to say to you... The words his mom taught him years ago.

dialogues.speaker: I_ HAVE NOTHING TO SAY TO YOU
dialogues.text: 81 82 83 84 85 Yellow Revision 10-11-13 60. In_ her room, Regina adds another article: "Fischer Withd from Monaco." We INTERCUT between articles and mini-scenes of Bobby's l road to the championship.

dialogues.speaker: IN A NATANYA HOTEL ROOM, (70'S ROCK CONT.)
dialogues.text: Bobby works out with weights as Lombardy watches skeptica

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: 23... 24... Push. PUSH...! 25! Bobby is wasted but he won't stop.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: One more set. He begins another set. Lombardy starts again at "1".

dialogues.speaker: RADIO ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Today, rising American chess champion, Bobby Fischer won his twentieth consecutive game... a world record. Bobby writes "mate" on his scorecard. The player opposite him has been crushed. Bobby hands the pen to Lombardy.

dialogues.speaker: DOC-STYLE
dialogues.text: Bobby is surrounded by FEMALE FANS swooning over him. Bob loving it. He turns to Lombardy.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: You sure we can't stay here a couple more days? Lombardy grins. Bobby is enjoying the fruits of stardom.

dialogues.speaker: IN A HOTEL ROOM, (70'S ROCK CONT.)
dialogues.text: Bobby lies in bed, listening to a tape recording. The CUL PREACHER is understated but authoritative. Like a father.  Yellow Revision 10-11-13 61.

dialogues.speaker: CULT PREACHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The tide of history is changing, friend. God's plan has left them behind, so they plot to take the world away from God... Lombardy passes by in the hallway, looks in.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: What are you listening to?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: The Worldwide Church of God. These people are into some heavy shit.

dialogues.speaker: CULT PREACHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: They will do anything in their power to destroy us. If we have any hope of surviving, we must expose them before the whole world... Lombardy walks out, shaking his head.

dialogues.speaker: DOC-STYLE
dialogues.text: Another interview.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I mean, what do we really know about radiation? ICBM'S? There are lots of things our government doesn't tell us. Regina adds an article: "Fischer Boycotts Fed for 2nd Tim

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO THE PARK, (70'S ROCK CONT.)
dialogues.text: An interviewer speaks to him, off-camera

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: So, Bobby, when did you last see your mother?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: ...-Uh...Haven't seen her in a few years, actually.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE MOSCOW APARTMENT 88
dialogues.text: As Regina tacks up the latest cover of Bobby's face. It's if she can hear him being interviewed.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: And your father...?  89 90 91 Green Revision 10-14-13 62.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE PARK 89
dialogues.text: Bobby's eyes flash.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Look, I thought you wanted to talk about chess. He summarily walks out of frame.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE MOSCOW APARTMENT 90
dialogues.text: Regina looks deep into her son's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: A HOTEL HALLWAY 91
dialogues.text: That same face. Manic mode. Giving orders.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: --What'd Vancouver come back with?

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: They've agreed to let you approve the lighting.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Good. What about the clocks? The BHB model with the button on top saves two seconds on each move.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Flying them in from Germany.  Green Revision 10-14-13

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: And the placement of the table?

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: They say there's not enough room in the hall.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: That's bullshit! Tell them I insist on a ten foot radius.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: But if there isn't enough room--

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I SAID, TELL 'EM! Now... What about the money?

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: They won't budge.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Then I won't play.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Bobby--

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Did you read Time magazine? (quoting) Quote. Bobby Fischer is changing the face of chess, single-handedly making it the fastest growing sport in the world. Unquote. (MORE )
92 Yellow Revision 10-11-13 64.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know how much Joe Namath makes? $250,000. That's 12K per game. And he's never won a single championship. I'm EIGHT TIME U.S. champ. You know what I make?

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: So what you're saying is you want to play for the Jets? Bobby senses Lombardy's gaze, turns to him.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: ...What--?

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: Just wondering what any of this has to do with chess. At the end of the hallway, FANS are waiting.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (to Lombardy) Gotta pen? Lombardy obliges; a fan hands Bobby an autograph book.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tu jeux aux echecs? The kid nods eagerly. Bobby grins.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Better not be good. I don't need any more competition. The fan is thrilled as Bobby signs with a flourish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Early 70's music. Joan is in booth, anxiously smoking a cigarette. Marshall is already talking as he sits down.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Joan, I'm between three airports and hell. I have ten minutes in New York to see my wife, kiss my kids and talk to you. How the hell have you been? You're looking great.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: I have to see him. Every time I call, they say his phone is broken.  Yellow Revision 10-11-13 64a.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: That happens.  Pink Revision 10-01-13 65.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: You mean he breaks them. I want to take him to see a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: That just won't be possible. He's already in Vancouver ...Joan, it's been a while since you saw him, right?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Over a year.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: I can tell you he's in great shape. Joan opens her purse and produces a pile of letters.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Every week his letters get more crazy. Go ahead, take a look.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: They're private letters to you Joan. I respect his privacy. Joan stares at him. Her face hardens.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: I showed them to a psychiatrist friend. He said Bobby is displaying signs of delusional psychosis.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Chess is a crazy world. Some of the things he says about the Soviets are true. In Tunis we found listening devices in his hotel room...

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: (reading) ‘The Communists infect my mind with words that just keep repeating’. Marshall blanches. He's not entirely without conscience.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ‘The Jews are helping them too. The Jews want to keep the chess federation all to themselves just like they own New York and own and control most Governments in the world’... (crumples the letter) We are Jewish. Bobby is Jewish. What do your people say to him when he comes out with this trash?  93 Yellow Revision 10-11-13 66.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Joan, I swear this isn't just about the title anymore. It's about the beauty of the games he's playing. (looks around) Out of all the crazy stuff -- such unimaginable beauty. A Da Vinci. From Brooklyn. Once every five hundred years... Grandmasters are watching Bobby play with tears in their eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Well, I have tears in my eyes too! Heads turn. Marshall checks his watch.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Joan, I'll take care of him. (touches her hand) I'll make sure his life doesn't get too crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madness. Reporters and photographers converge on Bobby, Caption: Vancouver Interzonal, May 1971.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Today in Buenos Aires, American chess star -- Bobby Fischer -- beat Russian grandmaster Tigran Petrosian in the semi-final of the World Chess Championships... Marshall and Lombardy try to shield him as they hurry dow the steps of the hall. Bobby is wired as hell.

dialogues.speaker: VANCOUVER REPORTER
dialogues.text: Bobby, with this win you're guaranteed a shot at the title. How's it feel?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Pretty good, pretty good.

dialogues.speaker: VANCOUVER REPORTER
dialogues.text: The Russians are saying you don't have a chance against Spassky. Any comment on that?  Yellow Revision 10-11-13 66A.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Okay, okay, I'm making this up as I say it, right, so it might not come out so good... Cameras roll and flashlights POP...

dialogues.speaker: VANCOUVER REPORTER 2
dialogues.text: Hey Bobby, big angry look over here... Lombardy gently urges Bobby forward. Marshall holds back.  94 Green Revision 10-14-13 67.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I just crushed Petrosian six-and-a- half to two-and-a-half. They know what I'm going to do to Spassky. ee ee

dialogues.speaker: VANCOUVER REPORTER
dialogues.text: Bobby, a crazy look over here.... * Lombardy pushes Bobby toward a waiting limo.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: They're scared now. That's why they bugged the phone in my hotel room. Murmurs among the press. Lombardy shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They point things at my window from * across the street. I wouldn't be * surprised if they were bugging me right now. Sometimes I hear stuff * buzzing in my clothes. I've even heard they can listen through the fillings in your teeth. Lombardy pushes Bobby into the car. A reporter follows.

dialogues.speaker: VANCOUVER REPORTER 2
dialogues.text: Petrosian said he wasn't well. That's the second Russian who got sick...

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Sick of me sure as hell. Laughter. Bobby grins. His mood swings are growing strong suddenly he's having the time of his life. Flashbulbs POP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby is grinning. Marshall puts an arm around him.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Bobby, Bobby, Bobby..!

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: Congratulations, kiddo.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Wide World of Sports is offering a * segment, Cavett wants you, and -- * are you ready...? Mike Wallace called. Mike Wallace. "60 Minutes," Bobby!  Yellow Revision 10-11-13 67A.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, about time... I don't want to be distracted by a bunch of press, though. I'1l do the big ones.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Great, great... Only-- when we do these shows... just go easy on the...bugging... and the teeth.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Whaddya mean? I'm telling the truth. People love that.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: I know, I know. You just need to be careful. Some things you say, they can be misinterpreted. People get worried when you talk like that...

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: People? What people?

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter... Which of these interviews do you want to do?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: No... You said people are worried. What people?

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Nobody. I think Cavett would be a great idea--

dialogues.speaker: -- WHAT PEOPLE
dialogues.text: Green Revision 10-14-13 68.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: eee wees Joan.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: You talked to Joan? When? Did you talk to her on the phone? Did she call you?

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: eeeee I was in New York. We had a cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: You MET with my sister without telling me?! You TALKED about me with my sister?!

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: She called me--

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: You think I'm a child who needs to be TALKED ABOUT?!

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: I was looking out for your best interests--

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Don't lawyer me!

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: I'm trying to help you!

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: DON'T LAWYER ME! You're having conversations BEHIND MY BACK! With my FAMILY?! Did I ask you to do that? Why wouldn't you tell me about that? Who's working for who here? There are a hundred more of you, you know, just waiting in line.  95 96 Yellow Revision 10-11-13 69.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Stop the car!

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Bobby, we're about to get everything you've ever wanted....

dialogues.speaker: STOP THE CAR--
dialogues.text: The car stops. Bobby jumps out. Lombardy turns to Marshal

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: I'll walk him back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lombardy catches up to Bobby and they walk in silence for moment. Then:

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: B6 to El. After a moment...Bobby responds.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: K4 to Qp4.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: P4 to P5. They walk on. For the moment Bobby is back on track.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marshall is eating alone.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: He's back in his room. He sits down opposite Marshall.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Is he okay?  Yellow Revision 10-11-13 70.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: He's in there listening to those tapes of his.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Isn't it some kind of God Squad?

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: Those people have as much to do with God as you do.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: I'd've thought you'd approve... He leans across the table.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Should we get him to see a someone, a psychiatrist.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: Never happen.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: We have to try. (looks at him) The concierge told me he asked for the TV to be removed from his room because he thinks the Russians are watching him through the screen.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: Maybe they are.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: He also believes they are going to try to blow up his plane.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: He just needs some sleep. What good would a doctor do?

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: He could give a diagnosis... He could give him a pill. The two men stare at each other.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: And that would be like pouring concrete down a holy well.  97 Yellow Revision 10-11-13 70A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boris Spassky rides a stallion bare-chested. He is a man ease. Reaching the crest he pulls up. Below a Lada waits. The sight of the car breaks the spell. Boris trots over to where Livo Nei leans on the car, smok a cigarette. Nei's presence means there is news...  98 99 100 Green Revision 10-14-13 71.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The press pack awaits the flight from Buenos Aires. Lomba emerges from arrivals, followed by Marshall.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO ANCHOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Bobby Fischer -- the first American in history to reach the final -- arrived in Reykjavik today.... Bobby emerges...with a brown paper bag over his head with eyes cut for holes. Cameras POP...the real madness has be

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE ARE INSIDE the paper bag. Frantic breathing, the bag sucking in and out. The press is SCREAMING, "You've never beaten Spassky. Why do you think you can you beat him now

dialogues.speaker: RADIO ANCHOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: After months of negotiation, Fischer will now face the current World Champion Boris Spassky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan is getting her kids ready for school. The radio is o

dialogues.speaker: RADIO ANCHOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The Fischer Spassky final will be televised world wide-- Joan's son comes running up the path.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO ANCHOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: --and is already being billed as the deciding battle in the war of ideas between East and West. Joan's son bursts through the door, breathless...

dialogues.speaker: JOAN'S DAUGHTER
dialogues.text: Mama, there are men on the lawn. Joan looks out and sees the press pack gathering on her l 98 99 100

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yellow Revision 10-11-13 72.

dialogues.speaker: DICK CAVETT, (VO)
dialogues.text: Ladies and Gentlemen, my next guest was US Chess Champion at fourteen and a Grandmaster at fifteen--

dialogues.speaker: DICK CAVETT
dialogues.text: --And now he's hoping to become Chess Champion of the whole world, Ladies and Gentlemen, Mr Bobby Fischer... Bobby is sprawled in a chair, looking by turns shy and co

dialogues.speaker: CAVETT
dialogues.text: So where does a chess player live?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I don't live anywhere. Hotels mostly.

dialogues.speaker: CAVETT
dialogues.text: In the past, you've made some pretty strong charges against the Soviets, accusing them of, of...

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Cheating. Bobby grins. Laughter. Cavett glances at his audience...

dialogues.speaker: CAVETT
dialogues.text: Cheating is the word I was looking for... More laughter. Bobby is encouraged to go farther.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Cheating. Yeah, they've done a bit of that in the past.

dialogues.speaker: CAVETT
dialogues.text: An opponent once said you are like Achilles without the Achilles heel. Do you have a weakness? Silence. Bobby looks puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: ..-A weakness?...... No. He laughs easily. His lack of guile can be disarming.  103 Green Revision 10-14-13 73.

dialogues.speaker: CAVETT
dialogues.text: What's the best moment when you win at chess, what's the home run moment?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (his smile fading) When you break his ego. That's where it's at-- Cavett reacts with mock alarm.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: --When he sees it coming and he breaks up inside. When you're, like, crushing the guy... (stares into the lights) Crushing the guy. (his eyes wild) Yeah, that's where it's at. The easy grin is gone. His smile appears haunted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chaos. Marshall is checking travel documents. A couple of SECURITY GUYS wait by the door.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Flight to Reykjavik's at nine. We need to get to JFK by 7. The noise is compounded by MUSIC Bobby listens to on a portable cassette player. He is shirtless, doing push-ups

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: Does that have to be so loud?

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: He doesn't want the Russians to hear which plane we're catching.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (yells over the music) THIS GROUP IS INCREDIBLE! They get thirty percent of ticket sales at their concerts. I should get that.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: (yelling back) We agreed to twenty-five...  Green Revision 10-14-13 74.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (more push-ups) Yeah, well it's thirty now.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Bobby. You agreed. You signed.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, I changed my mind. Thirty or I don't go. The room falls silent. The other have 'told you so' faces He stares,

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: If I ask for thirty, they'll say you're scared to face him.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Don't try that psychology crap on me. Without me no one outside Russia would know this thing is happening. I am the light shining on this game. (standing up) All of you are here because of me... I am a hundred per cent of the reason-- no, that's wrong -- Spassky is the reigning champion -- I want thirty percent for him too. (pacing; manic) But understand one thing: I don't just play for myself. I play for Chess. triumphant, at Marshall -- who nods, conciliatory.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: I'll call them from the airport. (to the others) Okay, people, we need to get packed. Lombardy takes Marshall's arm, leads him into the next ro

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: He told me he doesn't want to go to Iceland.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: He wants to go.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: He doesn't know what he wants...  Green Revision 10-14-13 75.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: But you do. Lombardy just stares at him, fuming.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look, my job was to get him this match. How about you do your job...

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: What's that supposed to mean?

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Get him ready. Help him win.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: What have I been doing for three years?

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Babying him. Catering to his bullshit--

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: Keeping him from cracking up is more like it. This may be hard for you to comprehend, but he's a person, not a meal ticket or a political symbol or an instrument of US foreign policy.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: I am so sick and tired of your sanctimonious bullshit... If you don't have the stomach for this I suggest you go find a church, get down on your knees and thank God you don't live in Russia.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: What if something happens?

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Like what? Lombardy glances through the open door at Bobby, who has turned off the music and inserted a home-made tape of The Worldwide Church of God. Lombardy doesn't want to give vo to his worst fears.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: ---I don't know. Marshall shakes his head and turns back to getting ready.  Green Revision 10-14-13 76.* Lombardy heads into Bobby's room. The Worldwide Church of God comes from the tape player.

dialogues.speaker: CULT PREACHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: --and when you see how the tide of history is changing, friend, you see how desperate they are.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: Can you turn that off for a second?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: What's up...?

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: Bobby. If you don't want to go, then you shouldn't go. A long moment as Bobby stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I thought you wanted me to win.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: I do. Too much, maybe. But I think... all the pressure... is... bad for you.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I'm cool. Lombardy has to say it, whatever the consequences.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: ...You need help.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: What kind of help...? Oh. You mean psychology. You think I need psychological help?! You know who invented that, right? The Jews. I don't need anybody's help. I don't need the Jews' help, I don't need God's help. And I definitely don't need your help, Father. (looks at him) When I call you, 'Father,' I think, like, he's not my dad. Is that what you think? That you're my Dad?

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: I don't think I'm your dad, Bobby. ee ee  Green Revision 10-14-13 76A.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: You're not my dad because I don't have one. You know what you are? You're a loser. You couldn't beat Spassky so why should I? You quit so you want me to quit. Is that it, Dad? You'll feel better if I turn out to be a loser... LIKE YOU! Lombardy stares at him, then starts out. Bobby is immedia contrite.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (calling after him) Hey, I've been working on a new variation on the Indian Defense, wanna take a look?

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: Later. In the hotel room, Marshall has overheard the tirade.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Love how you handle him. Lombardy picks up his bag.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're not leaving for half an hour.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: (fighting back emotion) ..-I'll...take a later flight. He leaves. Bobby appears in the doorway. He FH HK  104 105 106 107 108 109 110 111 Yellow Revision 10-11-13 77.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Where's he going?

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Jesus has left the building, pal. We're on our own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Zil limo with a Soviet flag enters a military compound. They're escorted by police cars with flashing lights. In the back seat sits Boris, Geller at his side. A KGB gu sits at his other shoulder. Boris looks like a prisoner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A limo pulls to the curb. Marshall and the security guys jump out. Then Bobby appears. He looks like a hunted anim

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boris is marched through the airbase. One KGB guy carries his coat. Another carries his suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marshall, Lombardy and the security guys hustle Bobby thr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boris boards an Aeroflot jet. Russian soldiers salute. Ge salutes back but Boris just stares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby and the others ride up an escalator.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE TOP OF ESCALATOR 110
dialogues.text: Suddenly JOURNALISTS spot Bobby...

dialogues.speaker: JFK JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: There he is! Bobby shoves Marshall aside, turns, and runs back down th up escalator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby leaps into a taxi.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Drive, drive!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 112 Yellow Revision 10-11-13 Bobby sinks down out of sight as the cab pulls away. We HOLD on his face, eyes darting, as we HEAR:

dialogues.speaker: JOHANNESON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Ladies and Gentlemen, It is with great pleasure that I welcome the world to our little island--

dialogues.speaker: A112
dialogues.text: 112 Caption: National Theater, Reykjavik, Iceland, July 1st 1

dialogues.speaker: JOHANNESSON
dialogues.text: --for the most important sporting event in history. Joining us today are the distinguished Ambassador of the Soviet Socialist Republic TBD, and Ambassador Tremblay of the United States of America. A jostling crowd, news crews from around the world. The crowd applauds the Icelandic Prime Minister, JOHANNESON. nods to US AMBASSADOR TREMBLAY and his Russian counterpar

dialogues.speaker: JOHANNESSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Also the great match adjudicator from the World Chess Federation, Lothar Schmid...

dialogues.speaker: SCHMID
dialogues.text: Thank you, Prime Minister. I am honored, but confused. I was always led to believe that chess needed two people for a game. Unfortunately, so far, we only have one. Boris Spassky is sitting with Livo, Nei and Geller.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Happily, our Russian friends have managed to get here on time. We are indeed honored to have with us the World Champion, comrade Boris Spassky. Applause as Spassky smiles shyly and waves.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: However... it seems our American friends have managed to lose their famous Mr Bobby Fischer... He turns to US Ambassador Tremblay. The crowd boos.  113 114 115 Yellow Revision 10-11-13 79.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: One hopes they are not so careless with their nuclear weapons. The crowd laughs. The Soviet Ambassador smiles at Trembla who whispers to an aide.

dialogues.speaker: TREMBLAY
dialogues.text: Son of a bitch. Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: AIDE
dialogues.text: Mr. Ambassador, we have a problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As if frozen in time. Strips of aluminum hang from the windows. Chessboards are set up but covered with dust. Bobby sits alone at a chessboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: US Ambassador Tremblay is waylaid by JOURNALISTS.

dialogues.speaker: ICELANDIC JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: Mr. Ambassador, is Bobby Fischer's behavior affecting US/Icelandic relations?

dialogues.speaker: ICELANDIC JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: There's talk of the Icelandic Parliament asking for the removal of the US Air Force base--

dialogues.speaker: ICELANDIC JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: Is it true Fischer has demanded two million dollars to come to Reykjavik?

dialogues.speaker: TREMBLAY
dialogues.text: I love chess. The world loves chess. We are here to celebrate chess. (to an aide) Tell me Fischer is on a plane. The aide looks like he's about to throw up.

dialogues.speaker: TREMBLAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get him here! Even if you have to use a damn tranquilizer dart.  Pink Revision 10-01-13 80.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The apartment is in shadows. Bobby dials the phone.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Joanie, where the hell are you?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN'S BEDROOM 117
dialogues.text: Joan's in bed beside her sleeping husband.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Joanie?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Bobby, is that you? Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: .--I'm here.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: In Iceland?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: No. Here. Home.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: You're in New York?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Had to get away from them...

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Bobby, are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: The whole world is pulling at me, Joanie.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Stay there, baby. I'11 come in. He's a lonely little boy in a scary world.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: ...-They're asking me questions, making me do stuff. So many people. Crowding me. I can't think, I can't think about chess.  81.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: I'm coming now. You stay there. Bobby HEARS a CLICKING on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: You hear that? They're listening. They're always listening... At that moment there is a heavy KNOCK on the apartment do

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They're HERE! They're coming to get me, Joanie!

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Oh, Bobby.... The KNOCKING gets heavier. Someone is breaking down the d Bobby whimpers. Finally the door flies open and Marshall enters, accompanied by two HEAVIES we haven't seen before

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Hey, pal, we were worried about you. Bobby confronts them with fists clenched. Marshall gently closes the door and gives a slip of paper to one of his m The guy goes to Bobby's phone and begins to dial.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Hey! You pay for that call!

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Bobby, why'd you run away?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (a speed rap) I changed my mind the money's no good they're charging five bucks a ticket the hall holds eleven hundred, twenty-four games max...that's 132 grand! They should be paying me more we're capitalists, right?

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Big news. Just got us an extra 125K. It's like Marshall is gentling an escaped animal.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Some English chess nut. Wants to see you play so bad. The guy on the phone nods, holds up the receiver.  Pink Revision 10-01-13 82.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But it's not just me who wants you to play, Bobby. There's someone on the phone wants to speak to you.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: My mom?

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Better. Henry Fucking Kissinger. Bobby stares at the phone in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Henry Kissinger! On your phone. In Brooklyn! Pretty amazing, huh? Marshall gently takes the phone and offers it to Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: You're joking me.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Wants to speak to you on behalf of the President. Bobby looks around where the Communist Party used to meet He thinks he sees the banner hanging as it once did.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All these years you've been talking about America. Now you are America. Take the phone. Bobby takes the phone and puts it to his ear.

dialogues.speaker: KISSINGER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey, Bobby Fischer... Bobby takes a breath, almost sobs.

dialogues.speaker: KISSINGER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: This is the worst chess player in the world talking to the best. The President and I want you to do your duty for your country. What do you say? Bobby is at a loss for a moment. Then focuses.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I guess I'll go do my duty. Sir. 70's ROCK MUSIC KICKS IN.  Yellow Revision 10-11-13 83.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FISCHER APARTMENT, NIGHT, (MUSIC CONT OVER)
dialogues.text: Marshall emerges, checks the street. A bread van is parke nearby. Two heavies emerge on hurry him into the van..

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: No limos. We travel in disguise.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I will accept one seven five US. That's the deal, right? Half in cash. The doors SLAM shut and the bread van roars away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The van heads toward JFK.

dialogues.speaker: BBC ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This is the BBC World Service. American chess Grandmaster, Bobby Fischer, is believed to be finally on his way to Iceland for-- The announcement becomes an Italian broadcaster...

dialogues.speaker: ITALIAN ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: --his match with Boris Spassky. It becomes a CACOPHONY of radio commentary in various languages that Bobby is on his way.

dialogues.speaker: A BUS DRIVER
dialogues.text: Fischer is to chess what Ali is to boxing. I love him.

dialogues.speaker: A LONG-HAIRED HIPPIE
dialogues.text: --Least there's one reason to feel good about America, you hear me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father Lombardy watches a small TV, his emotions roiling.  123 124 125 126 127 128 129 Yellow Revision 10-11-13 84.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men in dark suits escort Bobby as he steps out of the van

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a black-and-white TV, a grainy image of Bobby emerging Reykjavik airport. Regina is watching. The announcer is Russian but we recognize the name 'Bobby Fischer."

dialogues.speaker: A MONTAGE OF NEWS COMMENTATORS
dialogues.text: John Chancellor, Walter Cronkite, Harry Reasoner -- all i breathless anticipation of the match.

dialogues.speaker: A TV SOUNDBITE, (MUSIC CONT OVER)
dialogues.text: As Bobby arrives in Reykjavik.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: This thing with me and Spassky. Instead of bombs we're having it out with little pieces of ivory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A police car speeds down empty Icelandic roads. Bobby sit in the back with Marshall, staring out at the bleak lands They arrive at the same house we saw in the opening shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby enters, takes in the beautiful decor.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Five bedrooms. Pick any one you want. Place even has a sauna. Bobby is incredulous....and moved.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: This is the first house I ever lived in.

dialogues.speaker: TV SOUNDBITES
dialogues.text: CBS News is all over it. ERIC SEVAREID (on TV) A chess craze is sweeping the nation. Sales of chess sets have tripled in the past weeks and stores literally can't keep them in stock...  Green Revision 10-14-13 85.

dialogues.speaker: VARIOUS IMAGES
dialogues.text: Kids playing chess at home, in schools, in the park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby is on his knees searching for listening devices. A gentle knock on the door and Lombardy enters.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Hey, they said you weren't coming. Bobby looks wired, sleepless -- but his vulnerability is compelling. Lombardy is full of emotion but he covers it.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: I'm your second. They look at each other. Three years have forged a deep bond between them.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Thank you. Father.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: Anything I can get you, Bobby?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Help me check for bugs. These cheaters'1l do anything to get me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marshall is signing contracts when Lombardy enters.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Couldn't stay away, huh? I get it. Yankees are playing for the pennant and you've got a front row seat. Lombardy just looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: B135
dialogues.text: Green Revision 10-14-13 86.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A billion people around the world watching two guys play chess. President Nixon has had a TV put in the Oval Office. (lights a cigarette) World War III on a chessboard. We lost China. We're losing Vietnam. We have to win this one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TV CREWS report in their own languages. The only words we understand are 'Bobby Fischer' and 'Boris Spassky'... Caption: July 11th 1972. Game One.

dialogues.speaker: ABC COMMENTATOR
dialogues.text: This is ABC's Wide World of Sports bringing you live coverage of the World Championship of Chess... Boris Spassky arrives, looking relaxed. News cameras shoo him as he steps out to cheers. No sign of Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: ABC COMMENTATOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Best of 24 games. Each win is worth a point, each draw is half-a-point -- the chess version of a fifteen round heavyweight prize fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Utter stillness. Schmid -- the adjudicator -- looks at the big clock above the stage. Boris sits erect in his chair, refusing to be psyched out The crowd is growing restless and SLOW HAND CLAPPING begi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Bobby approaches the stage, the SOUND of CLAPPING grow louder. He stops.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE STAGE
dialogues.text: FLASHBULBS signal Bobby's entrance! Some applause, some boos. As Bobby strides across the stage, Spassky holds ou his hand but Bobby walks right past him. He greets Schmid then waves to the crowd. 133

dialogues.speaker: B135
dialogues.text: Pink Revision 10-01-13 86A. Then Bobby seems to notice Spassky for the first time, sm

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Boris!  135 136 137 138 139 87. He lurches over, sticks out a hand.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How ya been? Good? You look good. Spassky is wrong-footed. Doesn't know if he's being fucke with. A BLIZZARD of FLASHBULBS as they shake.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMID
dialogues.text: Now we come together for the drawing of the colors. Boris takes two pawns, black and white, in his closed fis

dialogues.speaker: BORIS
dialogues.text: Choose... We now follow the word 'choose' as it travels West.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carmine and others watch raptly.

dialogues.speaker: BORIS
dialogues.text: Choose...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through a half open door, we see the backs of the Preside and his advisers watching TV...

dialogues.speaker: BORIS
dialogues.text: Choose...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: President Brezhnev is watching as well...

dialogues.speaker: BORIS
dialogues.text: Choose...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on Boris's hand opening in SLOW-MOTION.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMID
dialogues.text: Mr Fischer chose black. Mr Spassky will begin. Bobby and Boris's eyes meet. The applause crescendos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.  140 141

dialogues.speaker: B142
dialogues.text: 142 143 Green Revision 10-14-13 88. Bobby and Spassky sit absolutely still. Fischer's thumb a forefinger push his lips into a contemplative grimace. Boris moves his Knight to King's Bishop Four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The advisers look down on the stage. Bobby makes his move A whisper passes among them. Lombardy makes a note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIME-CUT. A large SCREEN above the stage shows the moves. Bobby studies the board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lombardy and Marshall stand together.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: So far, so good...

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: They're both following the Nizmo. A draw in the opening game is fine.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO THE STAGE
dialogues.text: Behind him, Bobby hears an official shift his weight. A piece of paper CRINKLES in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Could you hush... The official looks puzzled. Bobby tries to concentrate. A few COUGHS. Bobby looks at the audience and imitates a particular cough viciously. A few sniggers. Then... a low BUZZING, WHIRRING noise from behind him.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY'S PERCEPTION
dialogues.text: The sound of A CAMERA is like the rip of a buzz saw. An electrical panel BUZZES. The COUGHS of the audience are magnified as if in a TB ward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to normal sound. Bobby tries to concentrate. Can't.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: What IS that? Boris slumps back in his seat. Some eyes roll. 140 141

dialogues.speaker: B142
dialogues.text: 142 143  Pink Revision 10-01-13 88A.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That buzz buzz buzz... Schmid cocks an ear.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMID
dialogues.text: It is just a camera.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Buzz, buzz, buzz. Jesus. Bobby gets to his feet and begins to pace. The crowd begi to WHISPER. He turns on them...  144

dialogues.speaker: A145
dialogues.text: 145 Green Revision 10-14-13 89.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Could you all shut up? Could everyone stop? Silence. Then a deliberate cough from some teenager.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: (to Schmid) Coughing, buzzing lights. Cameras everywhere. I can hear them rolling. You're gonna have to do something... A couple of people in the crowd dare to boo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lombardy and Marshall share a look. An inauspicious beginning. Nei turns to Geller.

dialogues.speaker: GELLER
dialogues.text: He is deliberately trying to unsettle Boris. Help him. Lombardy sees Nei leaving and decides he too must go down

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lombardy and Nei race down the steps, two at a time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nei is speaking to Schmid. * Bobby looks out at the sea of staring faces.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: We have to get rid of the cameras. (points to a curtain) Behind there. I can hear them...

dialogues.speaker: SCHMID
dialogues.text: They are just TV cameras. *

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: And there's something wrong with the lights.... (looks at the board) It's too dark...I can't see what anything is. He looks out into the darkness. *  Green Revision 10-14-13 90.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And the audience.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMID
dialogues.text: What's wrong with the audience?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: They gotta move back. Then Spassky abruptly makes his move.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMID
dialogues.text: Mr. Spassky has made his move.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (pointing) And up there... You don't hear what I do... Lombardy looks up into the lights. Hears nothing.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY'S PERCEPTION
dialogues.text: The buzzing of FLORESCENT LIGHTS sounds like a SWARM OF W

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby swings his arms around, trying to shake it off. Fin he returns to his seat. Spassky studies him dispassionate

dialogues.speaker: BORIS
dialogues.text: You don't look so good Robert James... Bobby lowers his head, looks back to the board...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby tries to concentrate. A chair SCRAPES. He looks up, distracted. Looks back at the board. The SOUND of someone TALKING in the audience. He looks up again. With each distraction, Bobby is more unsettled. A cough SOUNDS like a CANNON, a squeak is a SCREAM. Bobby's eyes dart furtively. He reaches for a piece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lombardy returns to the gallery as Bobby moves his Bishop

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: He's inviting Spassky to exchange. (studies his notes) I hope to God this is a trap. Spassky makes his move. The Russian advisers all scribble

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Spassky's taking the invitation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby is in the throes of a full-fledged anxiety attack. His heart is pounding, his breathing ragged. Spassky knows it. He is a vulture attending his prey. Bobby is a slow-motion train wreck. The distractions begi to profliferate -- each one EXAGGERATED, the sound MAGNIF A SERIES of rapid CUTS -- like a deck of cards shuffling. Bobby is fighting for his life. He can't take it a moment more. He reaches out to make a move...

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: Ah shit....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We SEE the move on the large board. A GASP from the crowd  155 156 157 158 159

dialogues.speaker: A160
dialogues.text: 160 Green Revision 10-14-13 92.

dialogues.speaker: ABC COMMENTATOR
dialogues.text: That move will hit the front page of * every newspaper in the world tomorrow

dialogues.speaker: IN BROOKLYN 155
dialogues.text: Carmine closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: IN LONG ISLAND 156
dialogues.text: Joan shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: IN MOSCOW 157
dialogues.text: Regina clutches her chair.

dialogues.speaker: ANCHOR
dialogues.text: -- Because Bobby Fischer has made a huge mistake....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, onstage, Bobby leaps to his feet...

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I can still hear the cameras! (turns to the curtain) I want these people out of here... Bobby YANKS the curtain and drags two TV cameramen, blink into the light. The crowd begins to laugh, others jeer.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They were whispering! ! The crowd begins to BOO and then slow hand clap.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMID
dialogues.text: ...first game goes to...Boris Spassky. The SCOREBOARD reads: Spassky 1 Fischer 0.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby stalks away in a fury. He heads downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marshall and Lombardy race downstairs to catch up to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marshall and Lombardy manage to catch up to Bobby in a sm room used as a recreation area: a drinks machine and a pi pong table. Suddenly the noise of the auditorium disappea  Al61 161 162

dialogues.speaker: A163
dialogues.text: 163 Pink Revision 10-01-13 93.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: It's just one game. One point. You'll take him tomorrow. Twelve- and-a-half points is a long match. Bobby is breathing hard -- but then he stops and looks ar

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: The reporters will go after Spassky. We can slip out another way... Bobby is staring around in wonder -- studying the bare wa

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Bobby? Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: It's quiet in here. Marshall and Lombardy look at each other. They think Bobb is being crazy. Later we will learn he has just found the answer to his problems. INT. THE WHITE HOUSE, OVAL OFFICE Al61 Watching TV, the President throws his pencil in anger...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boris Spassky leaves to a hero's reception. Some wave Sov flags. The crows push against the glass as they pull away

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby's car heads home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby, Lombardy and Marshall ride in silence. When Bobby speaks, it is oddly detached, as if talking to himself.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: The board. When I look at it, I see nothing. It's always been...I don't know...alive. (shakes his head) With that move, I tried to make it come alive. I thought...maybe I could make it...alive again. Jolt it. It's never happened before. I don't get it........ He closes his eyes. Lombardy and Marshall look at each ot

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 164 Pink Revision 10-01-13 93A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boris' limo heads home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boris and Nei settle into their seats and the car pulls a Boris removes his sunglasses. He looks deeply weary.  Green Revision 10-14-13 94,

dialogues.speaker: NEI
dialogues.text: He broke apart at the first hard blow.

dialogues.speaker: BORIS
dialogues.text: He shot himself in the the head. For no reason.

dialogues.speaker: NEI
dialogues.text: You loaded the gun. Boris stares thoughtfully out of the window.

dialogues.speaker: BORIS
dialogues.text: My chess teacher taught me....A man who is prepared to commit suicide always has the initiative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lombardy brings Bobby a dinner tray. As he enters, we HEA another RECORDING of The Worldwide Church of God.

dialogues.speaker: CULT PREACHER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: ...We know the truth of history, friend, you and I. We see them everywhere, working through their banks and corporations, through politics and the media...

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: You should be preparing for tomorrow instead of listening to this garbage.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: You really don't get it, do you? This isn't about me, or Spassky, or even Russia and America. This is about power, absolute global power.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: Bobby--

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: You think they care about chess -- wooden pieces on a board? (his eyes are wild) They run everything. Behind the scenes, pulling strings in secret! Now I know who they are. Marshall has entered during Bobby's rant.  166 Green Revision 10-14-13 95.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Who? Who runs things?

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: (wearily) He's talking about the Jews.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: The Jews? What about the Jews?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: They've been there from when I started playing. They've always been there. Lombardy shakes his head and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: You got your ass handed to you today. If you don't get your head in the game, you're going to be humiliated in front of a billion people. Bobby is madly scribbling something, hands it to Marshall

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Give them this. He ushers Marshall out and slams the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lombardy is studying Bobby's disastrous move in Game One Marshall enters.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: What he did today makes no sense...

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: (hands him the note) Unless the rest of the games are played without an audience and without cameras he isn't going to show up.  167 168 Green Revision 10-14-13 96.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: (reading the note) * He'll only continue if the games are * played-- (a disbelieving pause) --in the ping pong room...??????

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: He says it's the only place that's quiet. He looks up at the ceiling. We HEAR the muffled recording

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And he wants a different board. * Says the marble makes too much noise * when he sets the pieces down. Shit. Shit. Shit. The kid has the world in the palm of his hand and he's throwing it all away. (thinks ) It's like you said about Morphy. Chess is destroying his brain.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: Chess isn't destroying Bobby. *

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Then why the crazy demands? It's like he wants them to say no. I think he's afraid of what happens if he loses.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: I think he's afraid of what happens if he wins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The audience sits in stunned silence. Boris steps onstage but there is no applause. He sits dow at the chess table. Bobby's seat is empty. Caption: Game Two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pastoral idyll. We find Bobby playing around, laughing with an Icelandic pony. He runs with it, strokes its mane  169 170 171 172 173 Pink Revision 10-01-13

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boris sits perfectly still. Schmid hits the clock and the COUNTDOWN to Bobby's forfeit begins. The audience doesn't move a muscle. Suddenly the door to the auditorium OPENS and all heads t But it is only a match official who freezes in his tracks The clock TICKS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby rides his bike through the hills. It's the most carefree we've ever seen him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boris's clock hits zero. A sigh from the audience.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMID
dialogues.text: Mr Fischer failed to show. Mr Spassky wins by forfeit. The SCOREBOARD changes to: Spassky 2 Fischer 0. Schmid reads from a typed sheet.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: According to Federation rules, Mr Fischer has 24 hours to indicate in writing that he wishes to continue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby is on his knees. A pony comes and licks his hand. Bobby checks his watch...

dialogues.speaker: SCHMID, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Otherwise, Mr Fischer will be disqualified and Mr Spassky will be declared World Champion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spassky is alone -- pacing -- listening to radio commenta

dialogues.speaker: RADIO ANCHOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What a disappointing turn. Experts are saying the match is Spassky's, regardless of what happens now -- Livo Nei enters, carrying a bottle of champagne. 169 170 171 172 173  174 175 176 Pink Revision 10-01-13 98.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO ANCHOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: --a two point advantage is considered practically insurmountable. A message card is tied to the bottle. Nei reads it aloud.

dialogues.speaker: NEI
dialogues.text: From Comrade Brezhnev. He sends congratulations on your victory.

dialogues.speaker: BORIS
dialogues.text: Victory? Nei opens the bottle and pours two glasses.

dialogues.speaker: NEI
dialogues.text: If Comrade Brezhnev says it is a victory-- (toasts) -- it is a victory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We repeat the scene that opened the movie -- The granite house at dawn. The police car approaching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scene continues where it left off:

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Bobby, please...get dressed, comb your hair. A long pause. Finally, Bobby looks up at Marshall.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Ping pong. Marshall's face turns to stone.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: I will report your words to the President of the United States. You have betrayed your country. May you rot in hell you crazy son of a bitch. Marshall leaves. Bobby looks...almost content.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boris is pacing, playing six boards at once. He wears pajamas. In his anxiety and fast movement he resembles Bo  177 178 Blue Revision 9-24-13 99.

dialogues.speaker: BBC ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The world chess championship looks to be ending in humiliation for the American, Bobby Fischer, whose demands that the game be held in a store room have led to widespread ridicule. Boris checks his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marshall holds a stack of telexes. He knocks.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: I have messages from a million people all over the world who want you to open this door. Silence. Marshall kneels and shoves them under the door.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You still have two-and-a-half hours. No reply. Marshall opens the door. Bobby is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boris prowls from chess game to chess game, he stops and stares at the empty chair on the other side of the chessb

dialogues.speaker: BORIS
dialogues.text: I know exactly what game you are playing and I will not let you win. Boris begins to speak to the walls and the furniture.

dialogues.speaker: BORIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I cannot win this way. (to the room) I know you are listening. You are always listening. He approaches the wardrobe and speaks with formality.

dialogues.speaker: BORIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mr Bubnov, Mr Geller, General Secretary Brezhnev, I know your listening devices can hear me. He suddenly HURLS a chess table across the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a moment, a KNOCK at the door. Boris half smiles to himself. It is Geller, also in pajamas.

dialogues.speaker: GELLER
dialogues.text: Is everything okay?

dialogues.speaker: BORIS
dialogues.text: What makes you think it isn't?

dialogues.speaker: GELLER, (DEFENSIVE)
dialogues.text: I heard you through the wall.

dialogues.speaker: BORIS
dialogues.text: I have made a decision... If I don't beat him, he will escape from this island in one piece. Geller picks up the overturned table.

dialogues.speaker: GELLER
dialogues.text: It's not your fault the American is insane...

dialogues.speaker: BORIS
dialogues.text: He is NOT insane! (shakes his head) If you think that, he has fooled you the way he has fooled everyone else. Boris begins to pace. His manic energy resembles Bobby's.

dialogues.speaker: BORIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He knows if we play I will destroy him. Crush him. So he uses madness as an excuse to avoid the inevitable. I will not let him slip from my grasp. I have him pinned. I am two games ahead. (yells)

dialogues.speaker: I HAVE HIM
dialogues.text: Boris starts to unbutton his pajama top.

dialogues.speaker: BORIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get a message to Fischer. Now. This minute. He tears his shirt off and throws it onto the bed.

dialogues.speaker: BORIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I will play him in the ping pong room. I will play him in the toilet if he likes. He will not escape! Boris stares at Geller with steely resolve.  179 180 181 182 183 184 Yellow Revision 10-11-13 101.

dialogues.speaker: BORIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tell him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old bicycle on the ground. An Icelandic police car approaches at speed. Marshall climbs out, cups his hands.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Bobby!!! !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby is tossing pebbles into the water. He hears Marshal

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marshall is still yelling as Bobby appears over the hill.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Bobby!! You won't believe it! Spassky has agreed to play in the ping pong room! Bobby picks up the bicycle and Marshall fears the worst.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where the hell are you going? Bobby casually begins to cycle away down the empty road.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: To the ping pong room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lombardy, Marshall, and Bobby are walking fast backstage.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: We've got two minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ping pong table and drinks machine have been removed. In the center is a simple table. Geller, Nei, and Boris enter. Schmid checks his watch.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMID
dialogues.text: If he is even one minute late, I will fine him. 179 180 181 182 183 184

dialogues.speaker: B185
dialogues.text: Green Revision 10-14-13 102. Then Bobby enters -- wearing a sharp suit. He immediately goes and sits down in his seat at the table. * Schmid gestures to Marshall, Lombardy, Geller and Nei.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Gentlemen... He is asking them to leave. They do. *

dialogues.speaker: SCHMID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Bobby) Perhaps you would be gracious enough to thank Mr Spassky for acquiescing to your demands.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I'm so grateful I'm going to let him watch me play. Spassky understands enough English to understand. He smil Schmid points to a small camera in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMID
dialogues.text: Only one camera. It does not move. It makes no sound. It will relay pictures to TV sets in every corner of the earth. (a frozen smile) So please, gentlemen, if can we remember...the world is watching. As Bobby looks around, a slow, satisfied SMILE begins to soften his face as he revels in the stillness. It is quie

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lombardy turns to Marshall.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: ..-Did Nixon really call you?

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: (an inscrutable smile) Game's starting...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby reaches out to make his first move. D4. Caption: Game Three Boris reacts to the move, looks up at Bobby, unsettled. *  Green Revision 10-14-13 102A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nei and Geller are stupefied.

dialogues.speaker: NEI
dialogues.text: What is he doing? He's never played this opening before. Marshall sees their reaction.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: What's happening?

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: He's playing the Benoni. Black. Two games behind. It's suicide. 185  186 187 188 189 190 191 Green Revision 10-14-13 103.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE PING PONG ROOM
dialogues.text: Spassky moves: Pawn to Q5. Bobby captures: Pawn takes Paw Spassky counters. Pawn takes Pawn.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE VIEWING GALLERY
dialogues.text: Bobby plays Pawn to Q3. Spassky responds Knight to B3.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: He's giving him the center of the board...

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: (to himself) Oh, Bobby...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hand-written sign reads...'Bobby Fischer sat here, 1961 The crowd watches a grainy image of Bobby and Boris on TV Bobby makes a move. The crowd cheers. A voice from the ba

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: What the hell are we cheering? We don't know if it's good or bad. The crowd all turn and hush him.

dialogues.speaker: TIME CUT
dialogues.text: Bobby and Boris exchange pieces -- a Rook for a Bishop. Then Bobby does the unthinkable -- he exposes his Queen.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE VIEWING GALLERY
dialogues.text: Marshall is speechless. Lombardy is incredulous and bemus

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: What the hell--? Geller and Nei look on, hungrily.

dialogues.speaker: GELLER
dialogues.text: Take it, Boris. Take it.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE PING PONG ROOM
dialogues.text: Spassky is clearly unnerved. He senses a trap but cannot see it. Bobby's queen sits exposed -- his for the taking.
187 188 189 190 191  192 193 194 195 196 197 198 104. He looks up at Bobby, who smiles inscrutably. Finally, Boris cannot resist. He takes the queen.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE PING PONG ROOM 193
dialogues.text: Bobby immediately counters -- taking Spassky's Bishop. Th precipitates A BLOODBATH: piece after piece is taken ina vicious chess version of a knife fight. Finally, the smoke clears and both men study the carnage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clerk and her husband are glued to the TV.

dialogues.speaker: BOOKSTORE CLERK
dialogues.text: A draw.

dialogues.speaker: GELLER
dialogues.text: A draw is good. We are ahead.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE PING PONG ROOM
dialogues.text: Spassky studies the board. Looks up at Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: BORIS
dialogues.text: (in English) You accept a draw? Bobby slowly shakes his head. No draw. Slowly, almost sadistically, he reaches out and makes a m Spassky goes white.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE VIEWING GALLERY 197
dialogues.text: They watch as Spassky makes a move -- which Bobby immedia counters. Another move. Another counter. Bobby is now bullying Spassky across the board. Geller and Nei are becoming increasingly upset.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE PING PONG ROOM 198
dialogues.text: Spassky studies the looming endgame, his face withering.  Green Revision 10-14-13 105.

dialogues.speaker: BOOKSTORE OWNER
dialogues.text: It seems the strange little boy has done it.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE VIEWING GALLERY 200
dialogues.text: Lombardy looks over at Geller and Nei, smiles sweetly.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: He hates draws.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE PING PONG ROOM 201
dialogues.text: After an agonizing moment, Spassky knocks over his King. The SCOREBOARD changes to: Spassky 2 Fischer 1.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The electronic newsboard announces "BOBBY FISCHER WINS GA THREE." Taxis HONK.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO COMMENTATOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: -- the first time Fischer has ever won a game from Spassky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lombardy is asleep when he HEARS a strange SOUND and sits in bed. He checks his watch. It's 3:30 am. He walks down the hall. A light SPILLS from under Bobby's door. From inside, the SOUND is much clearer now: SLAP. SLAP. SLAP. Bobby has been up all night playing chess alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Motel clerk and Donna stare at his TV screen. Caption: Game Four A businessman enters. The Motel clerk is totally engrosse

dialogues.speaker: BUSINESSMAN
dialogues.text: Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: MOTEL CLERK
dialogues.text: (to Donna) Spassky took Bobby's Bishop.  Yellow Revision 10-11-13 105A.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: So what? I took his virginity.  205 206 207 208 Yellow Revision 10-11-13 106.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Wait, wait... Bobby's making a move.

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: Excuse me...They drew game four last night.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: We know, asshole. We're watching the re-run. The SCOREBOARD now reads: Spassky 2 1/2 Fischer 1 1/2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The middle of the night again. A SINGLE LIGHT burns in th upper window we know to be Bobby's. And we HEAR a faint but now familiar sound... SLAP. SLAP. SLAP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby and Boris take their seats. Caption: Game Five

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cigarette smoke swirls. We reveal Regina watching, smokin On her black-and-white TV, Boris stands and begin to pace

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boris wanders the tiny room, unnerved. He meets Bobby's stare -- as if the two are alone in a prison cell. Boris sits down without taking his eyes from Bobby. Bobby implacable now, totally focused. Boris turns to Schmid, who is dozing in his chair.

dialogues.speaker: BORIS
dialogues.text: Excuse me. (Schmid stirs) There is something coming from my chair.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMID
dialogues.text: Your chair?

dialogues.speaker: BORIS
dialogues.text: It is a vibration. 205 206 207 208  209 210

dialogues.speaker: A211
dialogues.text: 211 Yellow Revision 10-11-13 107.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMID
dialogues.text: A what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geller and Nei huddle in front of a black and white monit On the screen, Boris is on his knees, examining his chair

dialogues.speaker: GELLER
dialogues.text: What the hell is he doing? Praying? Nei glances over at Lombardy, who looks up with a smile a if to say, 'Welcome to my life."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boris is kneeling, examining the steel tube legs of his c

dialogues.speaker: BORIS
dialogues.text: A sound of some kind -- maybe high frequency, I don't know...it is affecting my concentration... Boris glances at Bobby, who is staring at him impassively

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Buzz, buzz.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMID
dialogues.text: Game 5 goes to Mr. Bobby Fischer. The SCOREBOARD changes to: Spassky 2 1/2 Fischer 2 1/2 Cheers now for Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boris marches away in a fury, his entourage in pursuit.

dialogues.speaker: BORIS
dialogues.text: ...It is coming from the chair! Geller and Nei don't know how to respond.

dialogues.speaker: BORIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It was making a SOUND...! Boris sees their skepticism.

dialogues.speaker: BORIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have you never heard of Watergate? You know what the CIA is capable of? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yellow Revision 10-11-13 107A.

dialogues.speaker: BORIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (stomps off) I want this chair X-rayed!  212 213 214 215 Yellow Revision 10-11-13 108.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boris studies the x-rays while Livo Nei studies Boris.

dialogues.speaker: BORIS
dialogues.text: Do not let them swap it. Do not let this chair out of your sight. Boris storms out. Geller whispers to Nei.

dialogues.speaker: GELLER
dialogues.text: The American son of a bitch has driven us all crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not quite dawn. A single light burns in the upper bedroom and we know it is Bobby, having been awake all night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clock reads 4:00am. Bobby sits in a chair, staring in space. On the table before him is an unfinished chess gam Lombardy knocks and enters.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: Bobby? Bobby doesn't even hear him.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (louder)

dialogues.speaker: ..-BOBBY
dialogues.text: Bobby is in some half-awake fugue state. He looks up. For a moment it's as if he doesn't recognize Lombardy.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can I get you anything? A hint of recognition comes into Bobby's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: No. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: It'll be light soon.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: It's never dark here.  Green Revision 10-14-13 109.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: ...Do you want to talk about tomorrow's game? No answer. Bobby just stares out the window.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bobby, I just want to tell you...that the chess you've been playing...is... inspiring. My whole life, I-- Lombardy stops himself. Bobby isn't listening; he's far away. When at last he speaks, his voice is lifeless, expressionless with exhaustion.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I used to wish I was born deaf... Lombardy doesn't know what to say. Bobby's eyes are far away. He has wanted and dreaded this moment his whole lif

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's funny... at the beginning of a game there are so many options... and at the end....there's only one. He is talking about more than chess.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I want to go back to the main hall.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: You're kidding.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: But nobody in the first seven rows.

dialogues.speaker: LOMBARDY
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: It's okay. The noises have stopped. Nothing gets through. Lombardy doesn't know why but he is near tears. There's something so forlorn about Bobby at this moment.  Yellow Revision 10-11-13 109A.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's like there's no one there anymore. (a long moment) Not even me. He goes back to staring out the window. Lombardy stands there, not knowing what to say or do. Finally he walks over, takes a pen from inside his jacket and puts it in Bobby's pocket, then backs out of the room

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Applause as Bobby and Boris return to the main stage.  217 218 Green Revision 10-14-13 110. Bobby sits, stares at the board. Continues to stare at it Slowly -- almost imperceptibly at first -- the room begin to FADE around him -- just as in his childhood bedroom.
